conversation:
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. Let's not let an ancient squabble interfere with the task at hand.
Isobel: Not as ancient as you think. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: You seem to have a lot to say about my allegiance. Can we focus on the task at hand?
Isobel: I suppose that would be wise. We have a common enemy, after all: Ketheric Thorm. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I am already protected. My Lady shields me from the curse.
Isobel: For now, perhaps. But Shar can be fickle, and her love can prove fleeting. Do not turn your back on an advantage you may need... even a Selûnite one. If nothing else, it can aid any companions who travel with you - somehow I doubt Shar's largesse was extended to them.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Selûne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*
InternalNodeContext: Incurable wound imagery/memoriy fragment
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we? I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: Hold on - Marcus is a True Soul. He's here to kidnap you.

Astarion: I can't believe you let me do that. Killing all those people. A pleasant surprise.
Player: I wanted what was best for you.
Astarion: You sweet, sweet thing. I want what's best for you too, of course. And one wicked turn deserves another. So, tell me what you desire. What can I do for my dearest pet?
Player: I am not your pet.
Astarion: Oh don't be such a humourless little wretch - it's nothing but a joke.
Player: Then stop joking around and let's sleep together.
Astarion: You've earned it. But don't you want more - don't you want eternity? One more bite is all it would take? But if you want the gift of eternity, I can certainly offer you that. One little bite is all it would take. It would mean your salvation. Your eternity, despite that thing inside you. That's what you want, isn't it? To be mine? Forever?
Player: What if I don't want forever?
Astarion: What's not to want? We could be together for all time. My dark consort. My right hand. My most beloved spawn.
Player: After everything you went through with Cazador, you're going to make me a spawn?
Astarion: Oh that was completely different, I'd never hurt you. I love you. That's what you've been waiting to hear, isn't it? That's what you want? We could be together for eternity, ruling this world side by side. We could have it all.
Player: No, this isn't what I want.
Astarion: It seems I misjudged you. I thought we might have a future together - even an eternity - but perhaps you're not worthy. So. What's it to be, darling? Is this it?
Player: I hope we can work things out and stay together.
Astarion: Of course we can. You're the one that I want - the one that I love. And you could be so much more, if you want it. One little bite and you could be mine forever. My dark consort. My right hand. My most beloved spawn.
Player: Yes, that's all I want.
Astarion: Then it's everything you shall recieve. I will miss this warm flesh, mind you. I knew you'd come around. Shall we have one last night together before you join me in immortality? One for the road, so to speak.
Player: We shall not. I just need you to bite me.
Astarion: Impatient are we? Well who am I to deny you?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade to black and fade in as Astarion takes TAV into another section of the camp/a quiet secluded place. You are naked and vulnerable before him.
Astarion: On your knees, darling.
Player: No.
Astarion: Yes.
Player: No.

Astarion: I can't believe you let me do that. Killing all those people. A pleasant surprise.
Player: I wanted what was best for you.
Astarion: You sweet, sweet thing. I want what's best for you too, of course. And one wicked turn deserves another. So, tell me what you desire. What can I do for my dearest pet?
Player: I am not your pet.
Astarion: Oh don't be such a humourless little wretch - it's nothing but a joke.
Player: It doesn't feel like a joke. It feels like you mean it.
Astarion: Life's a joke, dear, but now we're the ones laughing. Oh my sweet, there are no vampires like me. And there never will be again. But if you want the gift of eternity, I can give you that. One more bite is all it would take. But if you want the gift of eternity, I can certainly offer you that. One little bite is all it would take. It would mean your salvation. Your eternity, despite that thing inside you. That's what you want, isn't it? To be mine? Forever?
Player: I wanted you to be free. It seems you never will be.
Astarion: It seems I misjudged you. I thought we might have a future together - even an eternity - but perhaps you're not worthy. So. What's it to be, darling? Is this it?
Player: I hope we can work things out and stay together.

Player: A beloved slave is still a slave.
Astarion: Oh don't be like that, I'd never want to control you. I love you. That's what you've been waiting to hear, isn't it? That's what you want? We could be together for eternity, ruling this world side by side. We could have it all.
Player: That does sound appealing...
Astarion: I knew you'd come around. Are you ready, my darling?
Player: I'm ready. Bite me. Make me yours. Fix me.
Astarion: I have been waiting so long for you. Come, give yourself to me.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade to black and fade in as Astarion takes TAV into another section of the camp/a quiet secluded place. You are naked and vulnerable before him.
Astarion: On your knees, darling.
Player: No.
Astarion: Yes.
Player: No.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick. Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will. But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: A servant of Vlaakith wants for nothing that her queen can't give.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Hold your horses - just hear me out. I can give you power. Anything you want! You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Just let me go. (Ability Score +1)
Astarion: I'm all for killing her, but let's get that power first, hmm?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: What'll it be, petal?
Player: You're a stain upon this land, but I will cleanse it.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Tch. I hear blood and guts make excellent fertiliser. Let's spread you over the soil and see, you little bollocks.

Isobel: Well! Now you have two. Just in case. I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Gandrel: Ah, stranger. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. An old hunter's trick - most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Astarion: You're a monster hunter? I'm surprised - I thought all Gur were vagrant cut-throats.
Player: Say nothing.
Gandrel: And more! We steal chickens, curse your crops, seduce your daughters - the list goes on. I wish I had half the power settled folk think my people possess. Alas, I am a simple wanderer. A simple wanderer and monster hunter. But I'm no witchdoctor or cut-throat.
Player: I assume you want to kill the hag?
Astarion: Or to make a deal with her. Probably think you can outfox the old dear.
Gandrel: Right, but very wrong. My prey is a vampire spawn - much less impressive than the beast that lives here. His name is Astarion, but I fear he's gone to ground. I hope the hag of these lands can help me flush him out, if I can afford her blood price.
NodeContext: The hag's 'blood price' is likely to be something that'll cost him dearly.
Player: Only a spawn? Pity. Not like it's a real vampire.
Astarion: I don't know. I'm sure a vampire spawn could still rip your throat out if he felt like it.
Gandrel: He is right, unfortunately. They are only weak when compared to their masters. During the day, we have the advantage. But at night, when they hunt? You will not find a more deadly quarry.
Player: Yes, I'm sure they can creep right up on you.
Astarion: We've all survived so far. Let's focus on that.
Gandrel: It would still be wise to post guards at night. The threat is real.
Astarion: Indeed it is. We should do something about this threat.
Player: We'll be careful, but we should get going.
Astarion: Don't you think we should do something about the... vampire issue?
Player: I said we'll be careful. Now let's go.

Raphael: There. Middle-of-somewhere.
Karlach: I don't like this at all.
Player: Can you be more specific than 'somewhere'?
Raphael: The House of Hope. Where the tired come to rest, and the famished come to feed - lavishly.
NodeContext: He spreads his arms as he dramatically introduces this place.
Raphael: Go on. Partake. Enjoy your supper. After all... ...it might just be your last.
Player: Ignore him and fill your plate.
Raphael: Not easily rattled, I see. Good. Makes the next part that much more straightforward. What's better than a devil you don't know? A devil you do.
Karlach: Fuck. A cambion.
Raphael: And so much more. Am I a friend? Potentially. An adversary? Conceivably. But a saviour? That's for certain.
Player: Draw your weapon.
Raphael: Easy, easy. I'm here to help, not harm. Consider your predicament. One skull, two tenants, and no solution in sight. I could fix it all like that.
NodeContext: He snaps his fingers on the word 'that'. As he does so, the candle flames suddenly shine unnaturally bright, bathing the scene in a hellish red glow.
Player: I'll do anything to get rid of the tadpole.

Isobel: CinematicNodeContext: Isobel not yet kneeling at corpse. What the hells is this?
Narrator: *Your tingling Urge knows her face - this is the cleric Sceleritas sent you to kill.*
Player: He was trying to kidnap you. When he died, a tadpole came out of his head.
Isobel: A tadpole? Maiden's milk - how could that be?
Player: I have no reason to lie. Marcus was a danger to you all.
Isobel: In that case, I owe you a debt of gratitude. You're the True Soul from the gate, right? It's a good thing you were here. I'm Isobel. And we have much to discuss.
Player: I've heard of you. You're protecting this inn - just not from Marcus.
Isobel: When you don't have eyes in the back of your head, it helps to have allies. Allies like you. Speaking of blessings... you'll be needing my protection spell. Let me guess: Jaheira's sent you to beg a protection spell off her favourite cleric.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: |Casts 'Protection from Good and Evil', but modified with Selunite (moon) magic to protect against the Shadowcurse specifically. Isobel can use the planned animations for this spell cinematically, or something bespoke as best fits the scene. (lighting tests in progree for clouds revealing the moon)

We see every present party member  take on a moon-like effect as a result of being targeted with the spell, which then fades as though absorbed by each of them. This gives them a special in-game status to protect them from the curse|

Narrator: *The blessing falls uneasily over your tainted body. You can't help but dream: to kill her would destroy all of Last Light. You yearn for it so deeply...*
Shadowheart: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Perfect. It'll make you immune to the lesser effects of the shadow curse, which will get you closer to the Towers. But there are places it won't help - places where the curse is darker. Stronger. The cultists are able to traverse even the deepest shadows, though. I don't know how - the Harpers are trying to figure it out.
Shadowheart: A gaudy display. Let's just hope it actually protects us.
NodeContext: Distaste (while keeping her cards to her chest re: her shar worship)
Isobel: Only a fool would doubt it.
Player: I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! If I'd have realised, I'd have spared the theatrics. In that case, you should be able to navigate a path straight to your target. That's good - very good. I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Player: Huh. I forgot I'd be cold to the touch once I changed...
Astarion: Not having second thoughts, are we?
Player: I don't want this after all.
Astarion: It seems I misjudged you. I thought we might have a future together - even an eternity - but perhaps you're not worthy. So. What's it to be, darling? Is this it?

Isobel: CinematicNodeContext: Isobel not yet kneeling at corpse. What the hells is this?
Narrator: *Your tingling Urge knows her face - this is the cleric Sceleritas sent you to kill.*
Player: He was trying to kidnap you. When he died, a tadpole came out of his head.
Isobel: A tadpole? Maiden's milk - how could that be?
Player: I have no reason to lie. Marcus was a danger to you all.
Isobel: In that case, I owe you a debt of gratitude. You're the True Soul from the gate, right? It's a good thing you were here. I'm Isobel. And we have much to discuss.
Player: I may be a True Soul, but I'm not like Marcus. The parasite doesn't control me.
Isobel: If I didn't believe it before, I certainly do now. Speaking of blessings... you'll be needing my protection spell. Let me guess: Jaheira's sent you to beg a protection spell off her favourite cleric.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: |Casts 'Protection from Good and Evil', but modified with Selunite (moon) magic to protect against the Shadowcurse specifically. Isobel can use the planned animations for this spell cinematically, or something bespoke as best fits the scene. (lighting tests in progree for clouds revealing the moon)

We see every present party member  take on a moon-like effect as a result of being targeted with the spell, which then fades as though absorbed by each of them. This gives them a special in-game status to protect them from the curse|

Narrator: *The blessing falls uneasily over your tainted body. You can't help but dream: to kill her would destroy all of Last Light. You yearn for it so deeply...*
Shadowheart: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Perfect. It'll make you immune to the lesser effects of the shadow curse, which will get you closer to the Towers. It won't be enough to protect you against areas of utter darkness, though - where the curse is strongest. This lantern should, though.
Player: Very nice of you, but I've been to Moonrise Towers already.
Isobel: You... have. Forgive me for gilding the lily. I suppose if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing into the night, there's work to be done there yet. I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. This Sharran exposed a traitor in your midst.
Isobel: Fair. I admit, Marcus waltzing around the place undetected bodes rather ill for our defences, doesn't it? Then again, the best defence is a good offence. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Selûnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selûnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: Silently petition Lady Shar for guidance.
Narrator: *She offers you nothing.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. It won't be enough to protect you against areas of utter darkness, though - where the curse is strongest. This lantern should, though.
Player: Very nice of you, but I've been to Moonrise Towers already.
Isobel: You... have. Forgive me for gilding the lily. I suppose if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing into the night, there's work to be done there yet. I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Hold on - Marcus is a True Soul. He's here to kidnap you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade to black and fade in as Astarion takes TAV into another section of the camp/a quiet secluded place. You are naked and vulnerable before him.
Astarion: On your knees, darling.
Player: No.
Astarion: Yes.
Player: No.

Narrator: *You don't sleep well, flitting between dreams and nightmares.* *Maybe you wake up because you know something is wrong. Or maybe you just get lucky.*
Astarion: ...Shit.
NodeContext: Hunched over the player's bedroll, about to bite someone, but they've just woken up and are looking up at you. More deadpan than urgent.
Astarion: No no - it's not what it looks like, I swear! I wasn't going to hurt you! I just needed - well, blood.
Narrator: *There, in dim firelight, you see him for what he really is: a vampire. A slave to sanguine hunger.*
Player: I can't believe I didn't see it - we even found the boar you snacked on.
Astarion: It's not what you think - I'm not some monster! I feed on animals! Boars, deer, kobolds - whatever I can get. I'm just too slow right now. Too weak. If I just had a little blood, I could think clearer. Fight better. Please.
Narrator: *A strange sensation courses through you, and your companion's mind unfolds, secrets half-revealed.*
Player: Push into his mind, searching for the truth.
Astarion: I - what's this? What's happening?
Narrator: *The presence deep in your mind is awake, unblinking. This is it. A single word pervades your consciousness: 'Soon'.* *His mind opens up, revealing cracked and quivering memories. At their heart, you see dark eyes, commanding you to feed.* *You open your mouth and bite down. Not into a tender neck, but into the twisting body of a rat - the only thing your master lets you eat.*
Player: Why didn't you tell me you were a vampire? Why didn't you tell me?
Astarion: At best, I was sure you'd say no. More likely, you'd ram a stake through my ribs. No, I needed you to trust me. And you can trust me.
Player: I do. I believe you.
Astarion: Thank you. Do you think you could trust me just a little further? I only need a taste, I swear.
Player: Are you mad? No!
Astarion: No. No, of course, silly of me to even ask. I'll go and find something on four legs to eat, I suppose. See you in the morning.
Player: No. Leave and never return.

NodeContext: Astarion gestures, inviting the player to lie down on the bedroll at his feet.
Narrator: *It's like a shard of ice into your neck - a quick, sharp pain that fades to throbbing numbness. Your breath catches, your pulse quickens.*
Player: Let him continue.
Narrator: *You lean into him, losing yourself. You can feel your blood racing, coursing through both your bodies. A gentle, numb feeling starts to spread.*
Player: Stop! It's too much.
Astarion: Ah! Of course. I was just swept up in the moment. But it worked. I feel good. Strong. Happy!
Player: You almost killed me!
Astarion: But I didn't. And that's what matters. And look what you've gained. Together, we can take on the world.
Player: You need to leave my camp. Now.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. I thought I smelled a Selûnite.
Isobel: At your service. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: You seem to have a lot to say about my allegiance. Can we focus on the task at hand?
Isobel: I suppose that would be wise. We have a common enemy, after all: Ketheric Thorm. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selûnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: Try to understand what's happening.
Narrator: *Is Lady Shar punishing you? Or perhaps testing you? Is it the tadpole, or a curse? You cannot say.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we? I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I do, though I already have a Moonlantern. I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! If I'd have realised, I'd have spared the theatrics. In that case, you should be able to navigate a path straight to your target. That's good - very good. I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Astarion: Now that you know what I am, I should tell you that Cazador was more than just a slaver.
Player: You said he was your master?
Astarion: My old master. Before the mind flayers took me from him. Before this strange, twisted freedom. Cazador Szarr is a vampire lord in Baldur's Gate. The patriarch of his coven and a monster obsessed with power. Not political power or military power - I mean power over people. The power to control them completely. He turned me nearly two hundred years ago. I became his spawn and he became my tormentor.
Player: Tormentor? What did he do?
Astarion: He had me go out into Baldur's Gate to fetch him the most beautiful souls I could find. It was a fun little ritual of his - I'd bring them back and he'd ask if I wanted to dine with him. And if I said yes, he'd serve me a dead, putrid rat. Of course if I said no, he'd have me flayed. Hard to say which was worse.
Player: Quite the sob story, but what's your point?
Astarion: My point is simple... The mind flayers aren't the only monsters out there. They're not even the only ones hunting us. All I'm asking is that you keep your eyes open. And watch out for anything lurking in the shadows.
Player: Oh no, my friend. If vampires come looking for you, you're on your own.

Astarion: I want to thank you.
Player: You're welcome?
Astarion: For what you said while I was in front of that vile drow. I spent two hundred years using my body to lure pretty things back for my Master. What I wanted, how I felt about what I was doing, it never mattered. You could have asked me to do the same - to throw myself at her, what I wanted be damned. But you didn't. And I'm grateful.
Player: You make your own choices now - for better or worse.
Astarion: It's been so long since I've had to make these decisions for myself. I won't lie, it's a daunting prospect. It would have been so easy to bite her. Player: Just repressed it and moved on? Sounds healthy.
Astarion: It's easy to judge a situation when you're not in it. The entire reason for my existence was to seduce anything with a pulse. And every instinct I have tells me that nothing's changed. That I'm still just a means to an end. You made me see I never stopped thinking like I was still his slave, even in freedom. But I'm more than that. More than a thing to be used.
Player: I slept with you because I wanted some fun, not to deal with this.

Player: How were you turned? Did he attack you?
Astarion: Not him, no. A gang of thugs attacked me, angry about a ruling that I'd handed down as magistrate. They beat me to death's door when Cazador appeared. It was only afterwards I realised just how long 'eternity' could be.
Player: Not a good master, I take it?
Astarion: He had me go out into Baldur's Gate to fetch him the most beautiful souls I could find. It was a fun little ritual of his - I'd bring them back and he'd ask if I wanted to dine with him. Player: You're free now. Enjoy that freedom.

Gandrel: Ah, stranger. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. An old hunter's trick - most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Astarion: You're a monster hunter? I'm surprised - I thought all Gur were vagrant cut-throats.
Player: Ignore the elf. He talks too much.
Gandrel: You should listen to your companion. Next he'll warn you that my people can curse your cow to give only sour milk and will seduce your daughter to a life of roaming. I wish I had half the power settled folk think my people possess. Alas, I am a simple wanderer. A simple wanderer and monster hunter. But I'm no witchdoctor or cut-throat.
Player: I assume you want to kill the hag?
Astarion: Or to make a deal with her. Probably think you can outfox the old dear.
Gandrel: Right, but very wrong. My prey is a vampire spawn - much less impressive than the beast that lives here. His name is Astarion, but I fear he's gone to ground. I was hoping the hag of these lands could help me flush him out, but it seems she is no more.
Player: Only a spawn? Pity. Not like it's a real vampire.
Astarion: I don't know. I'm sure a vampire spawn could still rip your throat out if he felt like it.
Gandrel: He is right, unfortunately. They are only weak when compared to their masters. During the day, we have the advantage. But at night, when they hunt? You will not find a more deadly quarry.
Player: Yes, I'm sure they can creep right up on you.
Astarion: We've all survived so far. Let's focus on that.
Gandrel: It would still be wise to post guards at night. The threat is real.
Astarion: Indeed it is. We should do something about this threat.
Player: We'll be careful, but we should get going.
Astarion: Don't you think we should do something about the... vampire issue?
Player: I said we'll be careful. Now let's go.

Player: Not a good master, I take it?

I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.

Ketheric Thorm: Kill them. Quickly.
NodeContext: Standing up to leave
Ketheric Thorm: Kill the goblins, too.
NodeContext: An afterthought, as he stands up to leave
Darra: What? No!
Drenn: You creaking old bag of shit!
NodeContext: Drenn grabs a halberd from a surprised guard and throws it at Ketheric.
Ketheric Thorm: Hmm.
NodeContext: KETHERIC stares at the halberd embedded in his chest in shock. Then, after a beat, he grunts in anger and pain as with one hand he grabs the halberd and pulls it free. The wound left by the blade is just a glowing purple gash, which disappears before our eyes, leaving his chest without even a scratch.
Disciple Z'rell: I'm so sorry, my lord. She's an unbeliever - outside my control.
NodeContext: Very apologetic - this should never have happened
Ketheric Thorm: Try again.
NodeContext: Ketheric drops the halberd on the ground and challenges the goblin.
Ketheric Thorm: Huh.
NodeContext: Just been stabbed, but is invulnerable.
Drenn: No - NO!
NodeContext: terrified - you know you're about to die
Ketheric Thorm: Dispose of the rest as you see fit. Or better yet - put that True Soul to use. They've proven themselves reliable.
Disciple Z'rell: Of course, my lord. Thank you.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Ketheric leaves the throne room
Disciple Z'rell: You heard the General. The goblins are yours - deal with them however you wish.
Player: What am I meant to do with them, exactly?
Disciple Z'rell: They are yours. You can release them, kill them, or feed them to each other for all I care. Just deal with them. Here, in the seat of the Absolute's power, your authority over them is complete. They will obey any command. Report to me upstairs when you're done.
Sazza: You wouldn't hurt me, would you? We're mates, me and you. Practically family!
Player: I'll give you a fair chance. Fight me - you either die, or you kill me and you're free to go.

Nym Orlith: You survived my brother? Let me know if you want to have a more calming time with me.
Player: Mamzell Amira said you could offer your services as a gift of her thanks.
Sorn Orlith: Or perhaps you have greater ambitions yet. Trust me, you don't want to miss my signature Menzoberranzan Love Trick.
Narrator: *Menzoberranzan love magic - a formidable practice, usually only reserved for pleasing the most insatiable matriarchs in the city of spiders.*
Nym Orlith: And is that your partner with you? What a gorgeous couple... perhaps we could come to an agreement.
Player: Menzoberranzan Love Trick? But you are Seldarine drow, why are you fooling your customers?
Sorn Orlith: Darling, we are not fooling anyone. Unless you pay for me to make a fool of you. You'll just have to see what is in store.
Player: Menzoberranzan Love Trick? But you are Seldarine drow, why are you fooling your customers?
Sorn Orlith: Darling, we are not fooling anyone. Unless you pay for me to make a fool of you. You'll just have to see what is in store.
Player: Menzoberranzan Love Trick? But you are Seldarine drow, why are you fooling your customers?
Sorn Orlith: Darling, we are not fooling anyone. Unless you pay for me to make a fool of you. You'll just have to see what is in store.
Player: You two look uncannily alike.
Sorn Orlith: We are twins.
Player: I suppose I haven't ticked incest off the moral atrocities to-do list yet.
Nym Orlith: Our bodies will haunt your dreams.
Player: I would like to hire both of you. And I hope my partner will join us as well.
Nym Orlith: We want both of you, silly! At the same time.
Shadowheart: There's an idea. If you're comfortable sharing... so am I.
Astarion: And don't worry, I'll dart out if I don't enjoy it faster than I used to run from the sun.
Halsin: Perhaps you'd care for a little extra company...
Gale: Well I suppose it would do no good to back out now. Let us begin this little anthropological study, if we must.
Player: No, Halsin! Tame yourself!

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh bollocks - I told those idiots not to let anyone through. YOU. Name, rank, and reason for interrupting an active crime scene. For your sake, the last one better be bloody good.
Player: Are you Devella? Valeria sent me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: To fetch her another bottle of mead, no doubt. Yes, I'm Devella, the unfortunate colleague. Unless you've got useful information, leave me to my work. Duke Stelmane's dead - and I've got to find who killed her.
Player: I know more about Bhaal than anyone you'll find. You don't want to send me away.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Unlikely?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: Show her the target list. Say nothing of your intentions.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'm glad you're on the right side of this, Bhaalspawn. You could be invaluable, if you can get on the inside. Hells, you might be the only one who can stop this. What else do you know?
Player: I'm planning to infiltrate the cult, but I don't know where to start.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Most of what I know is based on reading into Sarevok's history. I'm sure it's nothing next to your personal experience, but I'll share what I have. A century ago, Bhaal bred dozens just like you. One of whom was Sarevok Anchev. For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. That list you spoke of confirms I'm right. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: Not only is the cult back, it's spreading fast. I ran into some Bhaalists in the park.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: No doubt you found a trail of bodies in their wake? The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I tried to explain all this to my superiors, but they wouldn't have any of it. They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'm trying to hide from my Father's wrath. I fear what will happen if I delve too deeply.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Then I hope you can at least protect yourself, and pray this plot fails. But before you run and hide, there are a few more lives you could easily save. There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next. While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Karlach: InternalNodeContext: Companion confronts Avatar Astarion, telling him they know he's a vampire. Triggers if you make it to Act 2 without him telling you himself or revealing it via camp night bite scene/using bite attack in front of you. Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: I've hunted you to the Hells and beyond. It ends here, Karlach.
Karlach: For fuck's sake, you must be half troll to have a skull that thick. If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Astarion: Now, now, children - let's not lose our heads. Figuratively or literally.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name. I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: I'm sorry, Karlach. There's too much at stake.

Astarion: There you are, I was just thinking about you. And that delicious moment we shared the other night.
Player: The moment when you bit me?
Astarion: The very same. I've had this condition for two centuries, but truth be told? You were my first. In all these years, I've only ever fed on beasts. Drinking the blood of thinking creatures is a different thing entirely. You were delectable. And now I just can't help but wonder how the others taste.
Player: They might not be as open to the idea as I was.
Astarion: Alas. It doesn't hurt to ponder the question, though. I don't think they'd volunteer, of course, but it doesn't make me any less curious. I'm all too familiar with Gale's blood, unfortunately. I can't recommend it. But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: I'd prefer a beer, if it's all the same to you.

Player: This is still theoretical, right?

Akabi: ALAS - NO JACKPOT FOR YOU, UGLY ONE. BUT YOU MAY HAVE THIS.
Player: Nice trick rigging the wheel, but you need to work on your technique - it's obvious.
Akabi: You would accuse me, Akabi: Destroyer of Planes - of cheating? I am, however, feeling gracious. So, I will forget this and allow you to spin again. Or I can turn you into something vile. Choose.
Player: Forgive me - perhaps my eyes were mistaken.

Astarion: There you are, I was just thinking about you. And that delicious moment we shared the other night.
Player: The moment when you bit me?
Astarion: The very same. I've had this condition for two centuries, but truth be told? You were my first. In all these years, I've only ever fed on beasts. Drinking the blood of thinking creatures is a different thing entirely. You were delectable. And now I just can't help but wonder how the others taste.
Player: They might not be as open to the idea as I was.
Astarion: Alas. It doesn't hurt to ponder the question, though. I don't think they'd volunteer, of course, but it doesn't make me any less curious. Take Shadowheart, for example. She strikes me as having a heavy, enigmatic flavour - vintage port on two legs. But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: I'd prefer a beer, if it's all the same to you.
Astarion: Yes, heavens forbid we'd have an interesting conversation. Still, I am intrigued by the possibilities...
Player: Could I convince you to kill someone less useful?
Astarion: No one's getting killed, I swear. We're just two friends talking. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: I much prefer eating flesh to blood.
Astarion: I do appreciate your enthusiasm, but let's try to restrain ourselves a little. I just mean a sip of their blood. No mastication required. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: Gale, no question.
Astarion: I'm all too familiar with Gale's blood, unfortunately. I can't recommend it. But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: I'd prefer a beer, if it's all the same to you.
Astarion: Yes, heavens forbid we'd have an interesting conversation. Still, I am intrigued by the possibilities...
Player: Keep your eyes to yourself. You'll make people nervous.
Astarion: Relax, we're just talking. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: I much prefer eating flesh to blood.
Astarion: I do appreciate your enthusiasm, but let's try to restrain ourselves a little. I just mean a sip of their blood. No mastication required.
Player: That's it. We're done talking.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: What? I've got a duke's murder to solve, and not a lot of time to do it. Have you found something?
Player: I know a lot about Bhaal. I suspect he's involved with this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Unfortunate?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: I'm working against Bhaal - I found the murderer's target list.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods - that's it! Proof that I was right. Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right! I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this. I'll tell you what I know. A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal. He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network. There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself. Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar. For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. This list you brought me confirms I'm right. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: You said Sarevok led the cultists a century ago - he can't still be alive, can he?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Stranger things have come back to haunt this city. The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I've done everything I can within the remit of my job. Any more, and they'll fire me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. Follow the trail of these murders. Prove the truth. Use your lineage to get places the Fist can't. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: What about the other victims on the list, the ones who are still alive?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next. While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed. And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team. And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us. It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: When I murder her, Bhaal will choose me in her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: I would prefer to put my faith in your strength than the favour of your god. After all, it is Orin and this grand deception that he chose - not you. He favours her, and she is one of the founders of this insane cult. Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable. If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it. She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute. Now I know that those memories are lies. There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear. I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.
Player: Tempting, but eradicating the brain may be wiser, to put an end to this madness.
Nightwarden Minthara: Madness would be to let the Absolute's potential go to waste. The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: The future you propose is shaped by violence. I'd prefer to find another way.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'd like to hear her story first - I imagine it's quite the tale.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Gale: Come now - you're hardly in position to cast judgement on that score, are you?
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: What did the Dark Justiciar actually do to your friends?
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Yours is a classic tale of cowardice. Were you a character in a tale of mine, I would kill you off - immediately. You had the means to stop it - you chose not to. You let fear and cowardice rule you.

Oskar Fevras: Wait, WAIT! I'm just a prisoner - spare me and there'll be coin, I swear it!
NodeContext: Panicked, he just saw us kill a lot of people and thinks we're about to kill him
Player: Coin? You have my attention.
Oskar Fevras: Oh, thank the gods - if it's wealth you seek then you've done yourself a great service, friend. For you've rescued none other than the artist Oskar Fevras. Well, you should at least know what you've paid for. I am the Oskar Fevras, at your service.
Player: I am the [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53], at yours.
Oskar Fevras: A genuine pleasure. I'm in your debt - as is my patron. My betrothed, I should say. Assuming Lady Jannath still wishes to marry after our little... falling out.
Player: Ah, patrons dallying with their dashing artisans. A tale as old as art itself.
Oskar Fevras: Quite. It seems we are destined to doomed romances, are we not? She offered me a future, and so in a fit of madness I told her of my past. Of the woman I'd loved before she found me. Love still, in truth. She was... less than pleased. I made a timely retreat into the countryside. To paint, and clear my head. To choose, I suppose.
Player: I must know how this tragic tale ends. What option did you choose?
Oskar Fevras: Hm? Oh, absolutely none. Fame and wealth suit me very well, no doubt. And yet I think of that first love, and... I hesitate. Likely I'm going mad. Regardless! We have more immediate concerns - your reward once I've returned to the city, for one. Say - I don't suppose you could spare some coin, could you? Ease the discomforts of the road some?
Player: I can spare a little. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this. I'll tell you what I know. A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal. He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network. There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself. Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar. For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. This list you brought me confirms I'm right. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: You're not wrong about the cult. I found some Bhaalists in the sewers.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: No doubt you found a trail of bodies in their wake? The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I've done everything I can within the remit of my job. Any more, and they'll fire me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. Follow the trail of these murders. Prove the truth. Use your lineage to get places the Fist can't. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'll do my best.

Sazza: It ain't our fault, General! We did as we were told -
Disciple Z'rell: The facts suggest otherwise. You were ordered to retrieve the artefact - you failed to do so.
Sazza: We did as you lot told us. Minthara's the one who -
Disciple Z'rell: Enough!
NodeContext: Via mind meld
Narrator: *A blast of mental energy washes over you, filling the room. Your tadpole squirms, urging you to obey.*
Disciple Z'rell: You failed to retrieve the artefact. You failed to protect your True Soul. You do not deserve to live.
Player: Don't kill them! They're loyal followers of the Absolute. Hear, hear!
Narrator: *As the General's attention shifts to you, a memory stirs - a memory of this room, and his voice raised in anger.*
Player: Hear, hear!
Ketheric Thorm: Ah, the True Soul who delivered a grove of non-believers into the Absolute's arms.
Sazza: You! Me old mate that saved me from the tieflings -
Disciple Z'rell: Silence!
NodeContext: Almost bored with the proceedings. Wanting to fob off judgement to someone else. He's thisclose to getting his daughter back; punishing goblins doesn't interest him.
Player: Death is probably too good for them.
Ketheric Thorm: Alas, it's the best option we have.
Drenn: You ain't serious. You can't be.
Ketheric Thorm: Kill them. Quickly.
NodeContext: Standing up to leave
Ketheric Thorm: Kill the goblins, too.
NodeContext: An afterthought, as he stands up to leave
Sazza: What? No!
Drenn: You creaking old bag of shit!
NodeContext: Drenn grabs a halberd from a surprised guard and throws it at Ketheric.
Ketheric Thorm: Hmm.
NodeContext: KETHERIC stares at the halberd embedded in his chest in shock. Then, after a beat, he grunts in anger and pain as with one hand he grabs the halberd and pulls it free. The wound left by the blade is just a glowing purple gash, which disappears before our eyes, leaving his chest without even a scratch.
Disciple Z'rell: I'm so sorry, my lord. She's an unbeliever - outside my control.
NodeContext: Very apologetic - this should never have happened
Ketheric Thorm: Try again.
NodeContext: Ketheric drops the halberd on the ground and challenges the goblin.
Ketheric Thorm: Huh.
NodeContext: Just been stabbed, but is invulnerable.
Drenn: No - NO!
NodeContext: terrified - you know you're about to die
Ketheric Thorm: Dispose of the rest as you see fit. Or better yet - put that True Soul to use. You have far more important matters to attend to - or have you forgotten?
Disciple Z'rell: Of course not, my lord. Thank you.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Ketheric leaves the throne room
Disciple Z'rell: You heard the General. The goblins are yours - deal with them however you wish.
Player: Nod curtly.
Disciple Z'rell: Here, in the seat of the Absolute's power, your authority over them is complete. They will obey any command. Report to me upstairs when you're done.
Sazza: You wouldn't hurt me, would you? We're mates, me and you. Practically family!
Player: An animal shows its true strength only when cornered. Show me yours. FIGHT. I'll give you a fair chance. Fight me - you either die, or you kill me and you're free to go.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered. Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: When punishment is needed, my hand will not shy from the blade.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: What did the Dark Justiciar actually do to your friends?
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Stop. You were willing to hurt yourself - that is enough for me.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh bollocks - I told those idiots not to let anyone through. YOU. Name, rank, and reason for interrupting an active crime scene. For your sake, the last one better be bloody good.
Player: Are you Devella? Valeria sent me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: To fetch her another bottle of mead, no doubt. Yes, I'm Devella, the unfortunate colleague. Unless you've got useful information, leave me to my work. Duke Stelmane's dead - and I've got to find who killed her.
Player: I know more about Bhaal than anyone you'll find. You don't want to send me away.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Unfortunate?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: Show her the target list. Say nothing of your intentions.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'm glad you're on the right side of this, Bhaalspawn. You could be invaluable, if you can get on the inside. Hells, you might be the only one who can stop this. What else do you know?
Player: Bhaal is trying to force me to be his Chosen. I'm doing all I can to resist him.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: So it's all happening again... just like in Sarevok's time... A century ago, Bhaal bred dozens just like you. One of whom was Sarevok Anchev. For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. That list you spoke of confirms I'm right. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: I think it may be a Bhaalspawn...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods save us all if you're right, but I'd believe it. Whoever it is, they are intimately familiar with Sarevok's work. The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I tried to explain all this to my superiors, but they wouldn't have any of it. They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: What will you do in the meantime?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next. While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it? Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.
 Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: My past is none of your concern.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: No offence intended, just being friendly. You won't find many make others making the effort. Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more. These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: I've got ways of making people share.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: The way things are going, it might well come to that. Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else. Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak. If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: You're supposed to keep the peace, not stoke the fire.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: What peace? If no one steps in, there'll be bodies piled high in the streets before long. We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: Both sides need teaching a lesson: let's kill them all.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Well? Have you found anything?
Player: I know a lot about Bhaal. I suspect he's involved with this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Abhorrent?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: I am working against Bhaal - I got a hold of the list of murder targets.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'm glad you're on the right side of this, Bhaalspawn. You could be invaluable, if you can get on the inside. Hells, you might be the only one who can stop this. What else do you know?
Player: I'm planning to infiltrate the cult, but I don't know where to start.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Most of what I know is based on reading into Sarevok's history. I'm sure it's nothing next to your personal experience, but I'll share what I have. A century ago, Bhaal bred dozens just like you. One of whom was Sarevok Anchev. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: What makes you think it's not Sarevok himself?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've not ruled out the possibility that it is Sarevok himself. The brutality of the killings is certainly reminiscent of his work. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I've done everything I can within the remit of my job. Any more, and they'll fire me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. Follow the trail of these murders. Prove the truth. Use your lineage to get places the Fist can't. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I've got better things to do than investigate a cult.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I suppose it was quite an ask... but perhaps you wouldn't mind doing me a different, smaller favour? There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next. While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Karlach: Oh, hi! Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: My sources say otherwise. Not a devil? Prove it.
Karlach: How should I do that exactly? Carve out my soul to serve with a nice side of turnips? If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name. I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: I'm sorry, Karlach. There's too much at stake.

Astarion: You know, I was just thinking about you. Remembering our little encounter in the night.
Player: When you tried to bite me?
Astarion: The very same. It obviously put me off your neck, but now I can't help but wonder how the others taste. Not that anyone's volunteered, it's just an idle fancy.
Player: I wouldn't expect any volunteers either.
Astarion: Alas. It doesn't hurt to ponder the question, though. I don't think they'd volunteer, of course, but it doesn't make me any less curious. I'm all too familiar with Gale's blood, unfortunately. I can't recommend it. But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: I'd prefer a beer, if it's all the same to you.
Astarion: Yes, heavens forbid we'd have an interesting conversation. Still, I am intrigued by the possibilities...
Player: Could I convince you to kill someone less useful?
Astarion: No one's getting killed, I swear. We're just two friends talking. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: Are you really asking which of our companions I'd eat?
Astarion: Oh no, don't be disgusting. I just mean a sip of their blood. No mastication required. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?

NodeContext: Whispered
Lunkbug: Tell the sergeant where she went - Beldron's still trapped with that maniac Nere!
NodeContext: Whispered

NodeContext: Whispered

Player: Fear not, gnome. I will protect you. Tell me what you know.
Apprentice Laridda: I - all right. Go ahead, Lunkbug. Tell her.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off. We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map. If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Karlach: Some firepower'll help bust open that wall. Then we can free the poor lads inside.
Player: I'll do what I can.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Well? Have you found anything?
Player: I know a lot about Bhaal. I suspect he's involved with this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Abhorrent?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: I am working against Bhaal - I got a hold of the list of murder targets.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'm glad you're on the right side of this, Bhaalspawn. You could be invaluable, if you can get on the inside. Hells, you might be the only one who can stop this. What else do you know?
Player: Bhaal is trying to force me to be his Chosen. I'm doing all I can to resist him.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: So it's all happening again... just like in Sarevok's time... A century ago, Bhaal bred dozens just like you. One of whom was Sarevok Anchev. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: Any idea who it is?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: No idea, unfortunately. But whoever it is, they are intimately familiar with Sarevok's work. The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I tried to explain all this to my superiors, but they wouldn't have any of it. They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. Follow the trail of these murders. Prove the truth. Use your lineage to get places the Fist can't. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'll do my best.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: You really are a godsend. But - one more thing... There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next. While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence? It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on. In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope. He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored. He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Please, give me more boring details about your plans.
Raphael: Come now, we're about to unveil your destiny - you should be quivering in anticipation.
 And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny. As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr. In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed. The Rite of Profane Ascension. It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical. If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant. All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living. The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun. But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend. Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air. The only missing ingredient is Astarion. You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life. And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: You don't need to go back to Cazador - you're with me now.
Astarion: Do you think it's so simple? What do you think I should do?
Player: There's a way to become a living vampire... That must mean a lot to you.
Astarion: The idea definitely has appeal. I could get rid of the worm in my head and still walk in the sun. I'd finally be free of the hunger. And if I'm the key to this deal of Cazador's, perhaps I can turn this to my advantage... I need to take the fight to him. And I need you to help me.
Player: If he comes for you, I'll defend you. But we're not risking an attack on his lair.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: We're done talking about this, Astarion. My decision is made.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller. You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance. Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now. Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself. When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.
