Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Well? Have you found anything?
Player: I know a lot about Bhaal. I suspect he's involved with this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Abhorrent?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: I'm working against Bhaal - I found the murderer's target list.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods - that's it! Proof that I was right. Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right! I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this. I'll tell you what I know. A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal. He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network. There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself. Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar. For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. That list you spoke of confirms I'm right. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: Any idea who it is?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: No idea, unfortunately. But whoever it is, they are intimately familiar with Sarevok's work. The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I tried to explain all this to my superiors, but they wouldn't have any of it. They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. Follow the trail of these murders. Prove the truth. Use your lineage to get places the Fist can't. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: What about the other victims on the list, the ones who are still alive?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next. While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence? It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on. In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope. He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored. He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Stop stalling.
Raphael: As you wish. Brace yourself, Astarion - we're about to unveil your destiny. And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny. As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr. In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed. The Rite of Profane Ascension. It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical. If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant. All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living. The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun. But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend. Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air. The only missing ingredient is Astarion. You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life. And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: You're... quiet. It's unsettling.
Astarion: It's a lot to take in. What do you think I should do?
Player: I think you should run. If Cazador can't find you, he can't complete his ritual.

Astarion: How long do you think I can run? He has eternity to find me. He'll never leave me alone. I didn't think he would when I was just one more wretched toy for him to play with. But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faerûn. I need to take the fight to him. And I need you to help me.
Player: After we dealt with our tadpole problem, yes, I'll help you then.
Astarion: Once we deal with the tadpole, I'll be back to my nocturnal self. When you're being hunted by vampires, the dark is the worst place to hide. I need to deal with Cazador while I still have any kind of advantage over him. If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: We're done talking about this, Astarion. My decision is made.

Novice Grumm: Shit - True Soul Nere's nothing but grub-chow now. Listen up, bastards - I'm taking charge. Clean your 'nads and pack up.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Novice Grumm: We're marching to Moonrise. And no death-curse'll be stopping us.
NodeContext: Addressed to the room in general
Novice Grumm: Time for the General to recognise us duergar that have been toiling 'round here.
Player: What about the gnomes? What happens to them?
Novice Grumm: What - you'd think I'd just toss 'em? They're coming with me. A gift for the General.
Wyll: Speak up. You can't just let the clan keep them.
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.* *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*
Player: It's a tough journey. The gnomes will be a burden.
Novice Grumm: Shit - suppose you're right. No use hauling dead weight. Gnomes - it's your lucky day. Get your squat arses moving, before I take a brand to them.

Player: I am freeing these gnomes. Just try and stop me.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh bollocks - I told those idiots not to let anyone through. YOU. Name, rank, and reason for interrupting an active crime scene. For your sake, the last one better be bloody good.
Player: Are you Devella? Valeria sent me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: To fetch her another bottle of mead, no doubt. Yes, I'm Devella, the unfortunate colleague. Unless you've got useful information, leave me to my work. Duke Stelmane's dead - and I've got to find who killed her.
Player: I know more about Bhaal than anyone you'll find. You don't want to send me away.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Unfortunate?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: I'm working against Bhaal - I found the murderer's target list.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods - that's it! Proof that I was right. Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right! I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this. I'll tell you what I know. A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal. He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network. There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself. Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar. For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. That list you spoke of confirms I'm right. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: You said Sarevok led the cultists a century ago - he can't still be alive, can he?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Stranger things have come back to haunt this city. The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I've done everything I can within the remit of my job. Any more, and they'll fire me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'm going to stop my Father, whatever it takes.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: If anyone can, it will be you. Or at least that's what the legends say. But before you run off, do you think you could save a few more lives? There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next. While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Astarion: You know, I was just thinking about you. Remembering our little encounter in the night.
Player: When you tried to bite me?
Astarion: The very same. It obviously put me off your neck, but now I can't help but wonder how the others taste. Not that anyone's volunteered, it's just an idle fancy.
Player: I wouldn't expect any volunteers either.
Astarion: Alas. It doesn't hurt to ponder the question, though. I don't think they'd volunteer, of course, but it doesn't make me any less curious. Take Wyll, for example. A man of the people, very palatable, like a sweet cider. But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: I'd prefer a beer, if it's all the same to you.
Astarion: Yes, heavens forbid we'd have an interesting conversation. Still, I am intrigued by the possibilities...
Player: Keep your eyes to yourself. You'll make people nervous.
Astarion: Relax, we're just talking. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: I much prefer eating flesh to blood.
Astarion: I do appreciate your enthusiasm, but let's try to restrain ourselves a little. I just mean a sip of their blood. No mastication required. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: Gale, no question.
Astarion: I'm all too familiar with Gale's blood, unfortunately. I can't recommend it. But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: Something exotic, surely? An Amnan liqueur?
Astarion: Ohh, that sounds very appealing. I'm almost convinced.
Player: This is still theoretical, right?
Astarion: Absolutely. A mere thought experiment. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: Are you really asking which of our companions I'd eat?
Astarion: Oh no, don't be disgusting. I just mean a sip of their blood. No mastication required. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: I much prefer eating flesh to blood.
Astarion: I do appreciate your enthusiasm, but let's try to restrain ourselves a little. I just mean a sip of their blood. No mastication required.
Player: That's it. We're done talking.

Narrator: *The lantern gives off a chilly glow, protecting all in its vicinity from the surrounding shadows.*
Harper Elindale: Can - can you feel it? Light. Hope. I'd near forgotten how it felt. Good bye, and good fortunes. And do return to Last Light, should you need space to breathe.
Narrator: *You notice a tiny pixie trapped within.*
Dolly Dolly Dolly: Oh please, oh golly, me-oh-my, you must release me or I'll die! This lantern only lights the way when I am hurting night and day!
Player: Who are you?
Dolly Dolly Dolly: My name? My name is Dolly thrice; now won't you free me from this vice?
Player: Study the mechanism keeping the pixie trapped.
Narrator: *The mechanism at the lantern's base would usually govern brightness, but seems designed here to crush the pixie painfully.* *However, the lock trapping this creature seems simple - crude, even. The fuel inside must be changed relatively often.*
Dolly Dolly Dolly: I dare not name it, newfound friend. The faintest touch could spell my end.
Player: Turn the mechanism.
Dolly Dolly Dolly: Son of a - NO! STOP! PLEASE!
Player: Ignore the pixie. You'll be needing this lamp.
Dolly Dolly Dolly: I'LL GUT YOU LIKE A TEN-DAY-OLD IF YOU DON'T RELEASE ME RIGHT! THIS! MOMENT!
Player: My, you've changed your tune.
Dolly Dolly Dolly: If you prefer the kinder type, I'll sweetly slurp your guts like tripe!
Player: Release the pixie.

Player: Nice try, but I know interplanar swindling when I see it. You rigged the spin.
Akabi: You would accuse me, Akabi: Destroyer of Planes - of cheating? I am, however, feeling gracious. So, I will forget this and allow you to spin again. Or I can turn you into something vile. Choose.
Player: Fine. I'll spin the wheel.
Akabi: LET US SEE IF YOU HAVE LUCK'S FAVOUR.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The wheel spins.
Narrator: *You notice a glint in Akabi's beard - as it glows, the wheel moves away from the 'jackpot'. He is cheating.*
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The wheel lands almost on the jackpot, but then passes it - on a random prize
Akabi: ALAS - NO JACKPOT FOR YOU, UGLY ONE. BUT YOU MAY HAVE THIS.
Player: You're cheating. I saw you rig the wheel.
Akabi: You dare speak to me as if we were equals? You are a scrap of food in my teeth. The dirt beneath my fingernails. You are nothing. I am, however, feeling gracious. So, I will forget this and allow you to spin again. Or I can turn you into something vile. Choose.
Player: Spin the wheel, watching for an opportunity to distract Akabi.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Shot of the wheel spinning
Player: Simply watch the wheel spin.
Akabi: ALAS - NO JACKPOT FOR YOU, UGLY ONE. BUT YOU MAY HAVE THIS.
Player: Can I spin again?
Akabi: YES! DROWN ME IN COIN, AND PERHAPS YOU SHALL WIN THE ULTIMATE PRIZE.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The wheel spins.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The wheel lands on a random prize
Akabi: ALAS - NO JACKPOT FOR YOU, UGLY ONE. BUT YOU MAY HAVE THIS.
Player: You're cheating. I saw you rig the wheel.
Akabi: You dare speak to me as if we were equals? You are a scrap of food in my teeth. The dirt beneath my fingernails. You are nothing. I am, however, feeling gracious. So, I will forget this and allow you to spin again. Or I can turn you into something vile. Choose.
Player: Forgive me - perhaps my eyes were mistaken.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
Halsin: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck. You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it. I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: Sympathies won't help me to survive.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies. I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill. I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: All right. How do I help?
Halsin: My thanks. If you prevail, I'll owe you the debt of a lifetime. It's too late to stop things from here - the goblins are already marching on the grove in force. You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: Very well. I'll go rescue the grove.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: What? I've got a duke's murder to solve, and not a lot of time to do it. Have you found something?
Player: I know a lot about Bhaal. I suspect he's involved with this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Unfortunate?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: Tell her of the target list. Say nothing of your intentions.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods - that's it! Proof that I was right. Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right! I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this. I'll tell you what I know. A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal. He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network. There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself. Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar. For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. This list you brought me confirms I'm right. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: I think it may be a Bhaalspawn...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods save us all if you're right, but I'd believe it. Whoever it is, they are intimately familiar with Sarevok's work. The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I tried to explain all this to my superiors, but they wouldn't have any of it. They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. Follow the trail of these murders. Prove the truth. Use your lineage to get places the Fist can't. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'll do my best.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh bollocks - I told those idiots not to let anyone through. YOU. Name, rank, and reason for interrupting an active crime scene. For your sake, the last one better be bloody good.
Player: Are you Devella? Valeria sent me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: To fetch her another bottle of mead, no doubt. Yes, I'm Devella, the unfortunate colleague. Unless you've got useful information, leave me to my work. Duke Stelmane's dead - and I've got to find who killed her.
Player: I know more about Bhaal than anyone you'll find. You don't want to send me away.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Bhaal? That's exactly what I - wait. How do you know about that?
Player: Don't panic, but I'm sort of... his spawn.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Oh! Oh my. By Ilmater's rack, that's... that's...
Player: Unlikely?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: It's fascinating! I should arrest you at once, but - well, the Bhaalspawn crisis, it's the most interesting criminal plight in Baldurian history. If what you claim is true, you wouldn't be helping me here unless you were trying to end Bhaal's hold over you. Just like the wayward Bhaalspawn who saved the Gate before... You are here to help me, and not to sacrifice me, aren't you?
Player: I am working against Bhaal - I got a hold of the list of murder targets.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'm glad you're on the right side of this, Bhaalspawn. You could be invaluable, if you can get on the inside. Hells, you might be the only one who can stop this. What else do you know?
Player: Father has shown me visions - the Temple of Bhaal lurks somewhere in the city.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: So it's all happening again... just like in Sarevok's time... A century ago, Bhaal bred dozens just like you. One of whom was Sarevok Anchev. For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. That list you spoke of confirms I'm right. The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: What makes you think it's not Sarevok himself?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've not ruled out the possibility that it is Sarevok himself. The brutality of the killings is certainly reminiscent of his work. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I tried to explain all this to my superiors, but they wouldn't have any of it. They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'll do my best.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: You really are a godsend. But - one more thing... There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next. While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Oskar Fevras: Gods above - I said buy me. If you didn't have the coin, you might have just said.
NodeContext: Taking in a scene of carnage - he asked us to bribe his captors and instead we slaughtered them. Distaste at our methods
Oskar Fevras: In any case, I am a slave no longer - and your money troubles are over, rest assured. For you have saved none other than Oskar Fevras. Well, you should at least know what you've paid for. I am the Oskar Fevras, at your service.
Player: I've never heard of you.
Oskar Fevras: An affliction for which you cannot be faulted, this far from civilisation. But my patron will be most grateful for your heroics. My betrothed, I should say. A genuine pleasure. I'm in your debt - as is my patron. My betrothed, I should say. Assuming Lady Jannath still wishes to marry after our little... falling out.
Narrator: *You recall a recent scandal - a patriar of Baldur's Gate who wished to marry a commoner.*
Oskar Fevras: Assuming Lady Jannath still wishes to marry after our little... falling out.
Player: I don't care about your love life - I just want my reward.
Oskar Fevras: Ah. Right. Suit yourself - find me in the city and you shall have your reward. Say - you couldn't spare a little coin, could you? Ease the discomforts of the road some? Say - I don't suppose you could spare some coin, could you? Ease the discomforts of the road some?
Player: I can spare a little. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Well? Have you found anything?

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: You've had a busy tenday. I can't even imagine. Well, I'll tell you what I know. A century ago, Bhaal bred dozens just like you. One of whom was Sarevok Anchev. Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Good. Then your eyes are open to the truth. The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new... There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship. The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them. I've done everything I can within the remit of my job. Any more, and they'll fire me. But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out. I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'm going to stop my Father, whatever it takes.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: If anyone can, it will be you. Or at least that's what the legends say. But before you run off, do you think you could save a few more lives? There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next. While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Karlach: Something on your mind? Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: My sources say otherwise. Not a devil? Prove it.
Karlach: How should I do that exactly? Carve out my soul to serve with a nice side of turnips? If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Astarion: Now, now, children - let's not lose our heads. Figuratively or literally.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: How can I make peace with the monster I was sent to kill?
Karlach: You know monsters, right? Better than anyone. Look into my eyes. Can't you see I'm not what you think?
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: Save your breath. Let's see if this devil bleeds.

Gerringothe Thorm: YOU BROUGHT VIOLENCE. UNACCEPTABLE. BUT ALL CAN BE FORGIVEN. FOR THE RIGHT PRICE. WHAT DO YOU BRING?
NodeContext: a desperate, cacophonous howl
Player: Pain and death, usually.
Gerringothe Thorm: I REQUIRE GOLD.
NodeContext: Roared with a shudder of pleasure on 'GOLD'.
Player: Leave.
Gerringothe Thorm: YOU CANNOT LEAVE. YOU MUST PAY. I REQUIRE GOLD.
NodeContext: Roared with a shudder of pleasure on 'GOLD'.

Player: Fine. Take it all.

Shadowheart: I don't know what you mean.
Player: That ruined Selûne statue - it made you hesitate.
Shadowheart: It's nothing. Really.
Player: We have to be honest with each other. What is it you're keeping from me?
Shadowheart: You're not going to let this go, are you? You might wish you had... I worship Shar, the Mistress of the Night. It is my holy mission to oppose Selûne, her teachings and her followers. Ngh... it hurts... Now that you have the truth, please don't make a big fuss about it.
Player: Don't make a big fuss...? You've been lying to me!
Shadowheart: A lie of omission at most. I'm sure you have some skeletons of your own hidden away. Secrecy is everything for Shar's children. It's our code, our creed, our shield. I even keep secrets from myself - I had my memories suppressed, so that nothing I knew could be used against the Dark Lady. Once I prove myself, my memories will be restored. I'm not sorry I kept this from you. Not one bit. Though perhaps that might change, if you can show an open mind.
Player: I can't trust you. Best if we travel separately for now.

Astarion: There you are, I was just thinking about you. And that delicious moment we shared the other night.
Player: The moment when you bit me?
Astarion: The very same. I've had this condition for two centuries, but truth be told? You were my first. In all these years, I've only ever fed on beasts. Drinking the blood of thinking creatures is a different thing entirely. You were delectable. And now I just can't help but wonder how the others taste.
Player: They might not be as open to the idea as I was.
Astarion: Alas. It doesn't hurt to ponder the question, though. I don't think they'd volunteer, of course, but it doesn't make me any less curious. Take Wyll, for example. A man of the people, very palatable, like a sweet cider. But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: I'd prefer a beer, if it's all the same to you.
Astarion: Yes, heavens forbid we'd have an interesting conversation. Still, I am intrigued by the possibilities...
Player: Keep your eyes to yourself. You'll make people nervous.
Astarion: Relax, we're just talking. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: I much prefer eating flesh to blood.
Astarion: I do appreciate your enthusiasm, but let's try to restrain ourselves a little. I just mean a sip of their blood. No mastication required. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: I much prefer eating flesh to blood.
Astarion: I do appreciate your enthusiasm, but let's try to restrain ourselves a little. I just mean a sip of their blood. No mastication required. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: Are you really asking which of our companions I'd eat?
Astarion: Oh no, don't be disgusting. I just mean a sip of their blood. No mastication required. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: Gale, no question.
Astarion: I'm all too familiar with Gale's blood, unfortunately. I can't recommend it. But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: Something exotic, surely? An Amnan liqueur?
Astarion: Ohh, that sounds very appealing. I'm almost convinced.
Player: This is still theoretical, right?
Astarion: Absolutely. A mere thought experiment. So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: I much prefer eating flesh to blood.

Sergeant Thrinn: I'll be damned. Nere's gone and kicked it. Listen, you pricks. Grab your gear and get ready to move.

Sergeant Thrinn: It's time I met the General in the flesh.

Sergeant Thrinn: What else? They're coming with us. A gift to the General from his new faithful.
Wyll: Speak up, chief. You can't just let the clan keep them.
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.* *As the symbol glows, power courses through you. Authority.*
Player: Good idea. They will make a fine offering.
Sergeant Thrinn: Yes. They will serve the Absolute's Chosen.
Wyll: Your heart made of stone? They deserved freedom - and you denied it.

Sergeant Thrinn: I... I was wrong. I must free them.
Narrator: *Your blood runs quicker, feeding the gnawing absence at the centre of your mind.*
Sergeant Thrinn: Get out of here, squat-pricks - before I toss you all in the fires.

Player: I am freeing these gnomes. Just try and stop me.

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you? Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now. Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself. When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: By your words, any virtue delaying patience would itself be unvirtuous.
Havkelaag: And therein lies your fault: you would have us argue in circles until the egg hatches naturally. Time we do not have. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on. In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope. Raphael: Oh come, Astarion. We're about to unveil your destiny - you should be quivering in anticipation. As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr. In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed. The Rite of Profane Ascension. It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical. If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant. All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living. The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun. But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend. Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air. The only missing ingredient is Astarion. You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life. And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.

Player: You're a Shar worshipper, aren't you?
Shadowheart: ...I should have been more discreet around you, clearly. Yes, you're right. I worship Shar, the Mistress of the Night. Don't make a fuss, Selûnite - we may be at odds, but I have more important concerns than you right now.
Wyll: A Shar worshipper? Not my usual quarry - nor my usual ally.
Player: You could have told me. How long were you going to keep this secret?
Shadowheart: Forever, ideally. And you assume too much about what I can and cannot tell. Secrecy is everything for Shar's children. It's our code, our creed, our shield. I'm not sorry I kept this from you. Not one bit. Though perhaps that might change, if you can show an open mind.
Player: I can't trust you. Best if we travel separately for now.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'm going to punish her - throughly.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: Peace - speak your truth. We will go from there.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: My gorge rises at your sickening naivety.
Madeline: No - no that wasn't the worst of it. She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Prove you're sorry. Do it for Ben and Marc.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Stop. You've done enough.

Shadowheart: Selûne. As if mingling with a horde of goblins wasn't bad enough. Let's do what we have to, then get out of here.
Player: What's the problem?
Shadowheart: Selûne is a bad omen - just look what's befallen her temple. Though I'll grant it must have been impressive once, in all its profane glory... I wonder what happened.
NodeContext: Slight concession, glancing around an impressive temple
Shadowheart: No matter. I'll breathe easier once we're clear of this place.
Player: You seem to admire whoever left this place a ruin. Got something to say?
Shadowheart: Only that you're overthinking a simple deduction I made.
Player: You can trust me. I want to know what's concerning you.
Shadowheart: You're not going to let this go, are you? You might wish you had... I worship Shar, the Mistress of the Night. It is my holy mission to oppose Selûne, her teachings and her followers. Now that you have the truth, please don't make a big fuss about it.
Wyll: A Shar worshipper? Not my usual quarry - nor my usual ally.
Player: You could have told me. How long were you going to keep this secret?
Shadowheart: Forever, ideally. And you assume too much about what I can and cannot tell. Secrecy is everything for Shar's children. It's our code, our creed, our shield. I even keep secrets from myself - I had my memories suppressed, so that nothing I knew could be used against the Dark Lady. Once I prove myself, my memories will be restored. I'm not sorry I kept this from you. Not one bit. Though perhaps that might change, if you can show an open mind.
Player: I can't trust you. Best if we travel separately for now.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence? It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on. In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope. He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored. He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Spill it - this sounds fascinating.
Astarion: I'd appreciate a little less enthusiasm when it comes to Cazador and his horrors.
Raphael: Oh come, Astarion. We're about to unveil your destiny - you should be quivering in anticipation. Carved into that ivory skin of yours is one part of an infernal contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles and your former master, Cazador Szarr. In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed. The Rite of Profane Ascension. It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical. If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant. All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living. The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike you, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun. But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend. Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air. The only missing ingredient is Astarion. You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life. And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: Cazador is a piece of shit. We're going to stop him.
Astarion: Do you think it's so simple? What do you think I should do?
Player: We can't let Cazador complete that ritual. He could unleash terrible horrors.
Astarion: The end of my life among them. Just when I was starting to enjoy it. He'll never leave me alone. I didn't think he would when I was just one more wretched toy for him to play with. But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faerûn. I need to take the fight to him. And I need you to help me.
Player: If he comes for you, I'll defend you. But we're not risking an attack on his lair.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: The Absolute is a greater threat - we need to focus.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it? Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.
 Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: Not my first, but hopefully my last. It's not the most salubrious of destinations.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Ah. Maybe our city's finer qualities can win you over yet, though I'll admit, they're in short supply at the moment. Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more. These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: I'm not surprised. Tensions seem high around here.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: 'Tensions'? That's putting it mildly. Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else. Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak. If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: If the refugees have more than they need, it's only fair they give some back.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Too bloody right. But will they share? Not a chance. Those refugees have been leeching on our city for too long. If we don't show them we mean business, they'll bleed us dry. We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: They're innocent people. You can't just kill them!

Shadowheart: Selûne. As if mingling with a horde of goblins wasn't bad enough. Let's do what we have to, then get out of here.
Player: What's the problem?
Shadowheart: Selûne is a bad omen - just look what's befallen her temple. Though I'll grant it must have been impressive once, in all its profane glory... until someone razed it.
NodeContext: Slight concession, glancing around an impressive temple
Shadowheart: No matter. I'll breathe easier once we're clear of this place.
Player: You're far too eager to disrespect Selûne - what's going on?
Shadowheart: Nothing. Merely an observation. Only that you're overthinking a simple deduction I made.
Player: You can trust me. I want to know what's concerning you.
Shadowheart: You're not going to let this go, are you? You might wish you had... I worship Shar, the Mistress of the Night. It is my holy mission to oppose Selûne, her teachings and her followers. Now that you have the truth, please don't make a big fuss about it.
Wyll: A Shar worshipper? Not my usual quarry - nor my usual ally.
Player: Don't make a big fuss...? You've been lying to me!
Shadowheart: A lie of omission at most. I'm sure you have some skeletons of your own hidden away. Secrecy is everything for Shar's children. It's our code, our creed, our shield. I even keep secrets from myself - I had my memories suppressed, so that nothing I knew could be used against the Dark Lady. Once I prove myself, my memories will be restored. I'm not sorry I kept this from you. Not one bit. Though perhaps that might change, if you can show an open mind.
Player: I can't trust you. Best if we travel separately for now.

Fezzerk: We did as we was told, General! Followed every order -
Disciple Z'rell: The facts suggest otherwise. You were ordered to retrieve the artefact - you failed to do so.
Sazza: We did as you lot told us. Minthara's the one who -
Disciple Z'rell: Enough!
NodeContext: Via mind meld
Narrator: *A blast of mental energy washes over you, filling the room. Your tadpole squirms, urging you to obey.*
Disciple Z'rell: You failed to retrieve the artefact. You failed to protect your True Soul. You do not deserve to live.
Player: Don't kill them! They're loyal followers of the Absolute. Hear, hear!
Narrator: *As the General's attention shifts to you, a memory stirs - a memory of this room, and his voice raised in anger.*
Player: Hear, hear!
Narrator: *As the General's attention shifts to you, a memory stirs - a memory of this room, and his voice raised in anger.*
Player: Hear, hear!
Ketheric Thorm: Ah, the True Soul who delivered a grove of non-believers into the Absolute's arms.

Disciple Z'rell: Silence!
NodeContext: Almost bored with the proceedings. Wanting to fob off judgement to someone else. He's thisclose to getting his daughter back; punishing goblins doesn't interest him.
Player: Death is probably too good for them.
Ketheric Thorm: Alas, it's the best option we have.
Sazza: No - mercy!
Ketheric Thorm: Kill them. Quickly.
NodeContext: Standing up to leave
Ketheric Thorm: Kill the goblins, too.
NodeContext: An afterthought, as he stands up to leave
Fezzerk: What? No!
Drenn: You creaking old bag of shit!

NodeContext: KETHERIC stares at the halberd embedded in his chest in shock. Then, after a beat, he grunts in anger and pain as with one hand he grabs the halberd and pulls it free. The wound left by the blade is just a glowing purple gash, which disappears before our eyes, leaving his chest without even a scratch.
Disciple Z'rell: I'm so sorry, my lord. She's an unbeliever - outside my control.
NodeContext: Very apologetic - this should never have happened
Ketheric Thorm: Try again.
NodeContext: Ketheric drops the halberd on the ground and challenges the goblin.

NodeContext: Just been stabbed, but is invulnerable.
Drenn: No - NO!
NodeContext: terrified - you know you're about to die
Ketheric Thorm: Dispose of the rest as you see fit. Or better yet - put that True Soul to use. You have far more important matters to attend to - or have you forgotten?
Disciple Z'rell: Of course not, my lord. Thank you.

Sazza: You wouldn't hurt me, would you? We're mates, me and you. Practically family!
Player: I'll give you a fair chance. Fight me - you either die, or you kill me and you're free to go.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [opening, face-to-face]

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you.
Astarion: Oh marvellous, you've already met.
Karlach: If by 'met' you mean hoofing it through the Hells with this fucker on my tail. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Wyll: You fight in the Blood War for Zariel. You'll bring the Blood War to the Coast.
Karlach: Yeah, I stowed away on a mind flayer ship so I could bring the war home. Makes perfect sense. If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Astarion: Now, now, children - let's not lose our heads. Figuratively or literally.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Wyll: No. No second-guessing. The devil dies - now.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I don't know.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it. I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill. I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first. You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: Very well. I'll go rescue the grove.

Zevlor: Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: Is there a place for tieflings anywhere?
Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded. But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Karlach: Gods, these are those tiefs? Their whole city was dragged into Avernus for a while. Zariel was delighted. When they made it back out, I'd hoped they got their happy ending.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer. I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

NodeContext: Via mind meld

Player: Don't kill them! They're loyal followers of the Absolute. Hear, hear!

Player: Hear, hear!
Ketheric Thorm: Ah, the True Soul who delivered a grove of non-believers into the Absolute's arms.
Sazza: You! Me old mate that saved me from the tieflings -
Disciple Z'rell: Silence!
NodeContext: Almost bored with the proceedings. Wanting to fob off judgement to someone else. He's thisclose to getting his daughter back; punishing goblins doesn't interest him.
Player: Death is probably too good for them.
Ketheric Thorm: Alas, it's the best option we have.
Fezzerk: Mercy, General! Please!

NodeContext: Standing up to leave
Ketheric Thorm: Kill the goblins, too.
NodeContext: An afterthought, as he stands up to leave
Fezzerk: What? No!
Drenn: You creaking old bag of shit!
NodeContext: Drenn grabs a halberd from a surprised guard and throws it at Ketheric.
Ketheric Thorm: Hmm.
NodeContext: KETHERIC stares at the halberd embedded in his chest in shock. Then, after a beat, he grunts in anger and pain as with one hand he grabs the halberd and pulls it free. The wound left by the blade is just a glowing purple gash, which disappears before our eyes, leaving his chest without even a scratch.
Disciple Z'rell: I'm so sorry, my lord. She's an unbeliever - outside my control.
NodeContext: Very apologetic - this should never have happened
Ketheric Thorm: Try again.
NodeContext: Ketheric drops the halberd on the ground and challenges the goblin.
Ketheric Thorm: Huh.
NodeContext: Just been stabbed, but is invulnerable.
Drenn: No - NO!
NodeContext: terrified - you know you're about to die

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Ketheric leaves the throne room
Disciple Z'rell: You heard the General. The goblins are yours - deal with them however you wish.
Player: Thank you, I'm going to enjoy this...
Disciple Z'rell: Do - have fun. Here, in the seat of the Absolute's power, your authority over them is complete. They will obey any command. Report to me upstairs when you're done.
Sazza: You wouldn't hurt me, would you? We're mates, me and you. Practically family!
Player: I'll give you a fair chance. Fight me - you either die, or you kill me and you're free to go.

Zevlor: Aradin didn't make it? Pity - but he might've got more of my people killed, if not for you. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I have no quarrel with druids.
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: Maybe your people should have stayed in Hell.
Karlach: Excuse you.
Zevlor: It seems you're of a mind with our hosts here. But their ritual will force you out, too. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer. I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it? Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.
 Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: My past is none of your concern.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: No offence intended, just being friendly. You won't find many make others making the effort. Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more. These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: Is there anything I can do to ease these people's burden?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: I've been asking myself the same question. I wouldn't be the first to interfere. Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else. Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak. If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: I'm all in favour of re-education. It sounds like they have a lot to learn.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: I knew you'd feel the same way. People here have gone soft living behind the city walls, forgotten what it's like live one day from destruction. I say we march round there and slit a few bellies. Remind them how much worse things could be. What do you say? We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: I kill discreetly and with purpose. Openly murdering refugees seems rather clumsy.

Gauntlet Edwynna: No refugees. It is decreed. Halt! By orders of Lord Gortash, refugees are no longer allowed in the city. Turn around.
Player: I am Wyll Ravengard. I trust you will let me through?
Gauntlet Edwynna: Ravengard? More like the ghastliest tiefling south of Neverwinter. Uh-huh. Eyes open, body still.
NodeContext: "Uh-huh" as in, "Yes, I heard you and am going with it."
Player: Do as she says. Stand still.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark. You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance. Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now. Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Perhaps not. Patience is important, but cannot impede the other virtues.
Havkelaag: Then we are in accord - the time for action is now. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Disciple Z'rell: The facts suggest otherwise. You were ordered to retrieve the artefact - you failed to do so.

Disciple Z'rell: Enough!
NodeContext: Via mind meld
Narrator: *A blast of mental energy washes over you, filling the room. Your tadpole squirms, urging you to obey.*
Disciple Z'rell: You failed to retrieve the artefact. You failed to protect your True Soul. You do not deserve to live.
Player: Don't kill them! They're loyal followers of the Absolute. Hear, hear!
Narrator: *As the General's attention shifts to you, a memory stirs - a memory of this room, and his voice raised in anger.*
Ketheric Thorm: I'm surprised to see you again, True Soul. You are here to assist and not to meddle, I trust. I would remind you that while in my halls, you obey me - just as you would any other Chosen. I'm sure you will enjoy watching my justice enacted. You have to take what pleasure you can, after all, in your diminished state.
Narrator: *His smirk says everything and nothing at once. 'I know exactly who you are, and I will never tell.'*
Player: You know me, General?
Ketheric Thorm: Better than you know yourself, it seems. But we are here to deal with these goblins, not to speak of your past. Kill them. Quickly.
NodeContext: Standing up to leave
Ketheric Thorm: Kill the goblins, too.
NodeContext: An afterthought, as he stands up to leave
Fezzerk: What? No!
Drenn: You creaking old bag of shit!
NodeContext: Drenn grabs a halberd from a surprised guard and throws it at Ketheric.
Ketheric Thorm: Hmm.
NodeContext: KETHERIC stares at the halberd embedded in his chest in shock. Then, after a beat, he grunts in anger and pain as with one hand he grabs the halberd and pulls it free. The wound left by the blade is just a glowing purple gash, which disappears before our eyes, leaving his chest without even a scratch.
Disciple Z'rell: I'm so sorry, my lord. She's an unbeliever - outside my control.
NodeContext: Very apologetic - this should never have happened
Ketheric Thorm: Try again.
NodeContext: Ketheric drops the halberd on the ground and challenges the goblin.
Ketheric Thorm: Huh.
NodeContext: Just been stabbed, but is invulnerable.
Drenn: No - NO!
NodeContext: terrified - you know you're about to die
Ketheric Thorm: Dispose of the rest as you see fit. Or better yet - put that True Soul to use. They've proven themselves reliable.
Disciple Z'rell: Of course, my lord. Thank you.

NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.

Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: My gorge rises at your sickening naivety.
Madeline: No - no that wasn't the worst of it. She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: You had the means to stop it - you chose not to. You let fear and cowardice rule you.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller. You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance. Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now. Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion. When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you're planning to torture a child for a year?
Havkelaag: The child will be a better individual after my treatment than it ever would have been had it been raised in its natural environment. Any suffering it endures will therefore be worth it, for the child, perhaps for the whole of civilised society. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects. Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: What wrong has this man done to deserve such torture?
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture. Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure. We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: You do me an honour, but I am not worthy. Show me the way of Shar - I beg of you. I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.
