Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...
NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us
Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.

Player: Why were you in hell in the first place?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse. Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me. I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset. Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: So you want me to kill the people hunting you?
Karlach: Yeah. Can you handle it?
Player: Yes.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: It is so good to see you again! I can't tell you how glad I am that you didn't enter the House without me.
Player: I didn't have a choice - the door's locked.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm sure a locked door can't stop a brave adventurer like you. But even if you poke the locks or knock-knock-knock, you won't get far without me. Allow me to introduce myself. I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart. I am Hope. What little is left of her. A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT
Karlach: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse? Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: You must ask of the Orphic Hammer. Without it, the prince remains forever out of reach of my hungry weapon.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking
Player: I need to find my contract. Can you help?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Caveat venditor. Big mistake coming here while Raphael holds all the cards in his claws. But big mistakes correct bigger mistakes. Like scribbling your signature in the first place. Silly little mouse. But, yes. Hope can help. Your contract is here, in this House - it's...
Narrator: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhhttttt... Quiet... There it goes... Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid. I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
NodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.
Player: Formulate your questions using as few words as possible.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: Where is Raphael?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: BEHIND YOU Skipping across the planes, spinning plates, making deals with dukes and devils. He's a busy man. A business-man. But not a man at all, of course. He'll be home soon, though, and you better find the Hammer before he arrives. Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: Where will I find my contract?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: THE SAME PLACE YOU'LL FIND YOUR SORRY LITTLE SOUL WHEN RAPHAEL RIPS IT OUT The paper cage for your soul. Such a tiny thing, but it's one of his favourites. In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you. But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.
Player: No. I'm not telling you anything.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed. And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team. And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us. It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: We must be free if we are to rule - and to be free, we must destroy this cult, and Ketheric's co-conspirators along with it. I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: An old flame?
Nightwarden Minthara: Jealous? You needn't be -  when Orin is in my hands, her agony will nourish me. She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies. Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable. If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it. She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute. Now I know that those memories are lies. There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear. I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: We'll be heroes - the saviours of Baldur's Gate.
Nightwarden Minthara: Let them think that. There is a short path from saviour to ruler - a short and bloody path. I know it well, and we will walk it together. But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it? In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: Stealing an entire cult is a new one, even for me.
Nightwarden Minthara: In the long history of these Realms, few people have attempted anything so bold. We may fail, but we must try. The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: I fear we could lose everything if we try to take control.
Nightwarden Minthara: Nothing worthwhile ever came without loss. But together we have the strength to decide who loses. And to make sure it is not us. You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: If you go to Baldur's Gate, you're going alone.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without you - without the Prism - I cannot risk going to the city. The Absolute would take my mind again.
Player: You can stay with me if you swear to follow my lead.
Nightwarden Minthara: Fine. All I ask of you is that you keep an open mind. We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose. There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain. When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?
Player: To watch them suffer - I need no other reason than that.

Shadowheart: You and the pale fellow. You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: If that was any of your business, we'd have called you over.
Shadowheart: Wrong. Your business is mine. We're entwined, thanks to this. If we're to survive, we need to trust each other. And just to be clear, come daybreak, finding a healer is our first priority.
Player: Let's not abandon all caution. This is unfamiliar territory.

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: I heard what happened - that people were taken to Moonrise.
Alfira: I keep replaying it... over and over in my head. We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
 Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Wandering into the darkness was a stupid idea.
Alfira: And I regret it with every breath. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: If he hadn't listened to me, maybe his brother and sister would still be here.
Alfira: Don't say that. When I think of what would have happened if Cal and Lia weren't there... How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: 'When the night is dark, stars shine brightest.' So keep on shining. It's going to be all right.
Alfira: 'Heart's Requiem', right? The hero survives a war and rebuilds her life - stronger than ever. A tale worth remembering - especially now. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Nightwarden Minthara: I have been expecting you. The goblins tell me that you forced a confession from our prisoner. Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul? Little wonder that you serve me so well. It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.* *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.* *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: Even with the grove's numbers depleted, dealing with her there may be safer than fighting here.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin. Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.* *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Get out of my mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: Destroying this place is the Absolute's will. Would you defy Her?
Player: Open your mind to her.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...* *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect. If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I prefer to face my enemies rather than stabbing them in the back.
Nightwarden Minthara: How noble. I prefer to win. I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: I've done enough. The battle is yours to fight.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not. The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you? Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now. Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you're planning to torture a child for a year?
Havkelaag: The child will be a better individual after my treatment than it ever would have been had it been raised in its natural environment. Any suffering it endures will therefore be worth it, for the child, perhaps for the whole of civilised society. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse. I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: My ardents spoke of one of our kin that escaped a crashing ghaik slave-vessel.
Lae'zel: Ch'r'ai. Vlaakith's justice in flesh.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much, child. I am pleased to finally meet you. Interesting. My ardents reported that an istik survived the crashed ghaik slave-vessel. You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you. It must not have been easy to escape. I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares. You also killed Sarth Baretha. She was formidable. To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us. The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: What makes you think we are not? We are talking about the Grand Design - the restoration of the Illithid Empire. There is nothing of greater importance. But the weapon is the solution. I have heard it directly from Queen Vlaakith herself. It is how we will stop the mind flayers before they destroy us all. Hand it over.
Player: What do I get in return if I give it to you?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The ghaik are about to execute their Grand Design and you seek to bargain. P'hak'va. The weapon. Now.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I do not know what base, naive entities you have made deals with before - nor do I care. But I will humour your greed for a moment. What would you ask of an Inquisitor? Is that so? Well, then - humour me. What would you ask of an Inquisitor?

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now. Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse. I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours. Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Darkness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Karlach: What the fuck is this loon talking about.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain... We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well. And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution. How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.

Jaheira: I'll not pretend to understand why you, the enigma that you are, suddenly crossed our path, but I'm old and wise enough to recognise a sliver of hope when it crawls out of the dark. Tell me - why have you come here?
Player: I'm here on holiday.

Shadowheart: You're here. Just like it told me. And with a gith - I should have figured.
Narrator: *Your mind rushes into hers - a storm of desperation, confusion and a will other than her own.*

Shadowheart: It took me so long to find you.
Player: You're infected, same as me. How did you get here?
Shadowheart: Quiet! I can't... concentrate with all these voices! Just listen. The whispering won't let me sleep. It keeps pushing me - to you. Even when I'm awake, I dream. There's blood, there's so much blood. I can't sleep. The whispering won't let me. It keeps pushing me - to you.
NodeContext: On, " to you" SH's hand drifts toward a knife tucked into her belt at the small her back
Karlach: |Karlach get rid of her/hear her out|
Narrator: *There is a knife hidden in her belt. Her fingers twitch towards the hilt, ready to draw the blade.*
Player: Slow down - what whispering?
Shadowheart: They've been in my head ever since... it doesn't matter. They brought me here. I keep thinking about the knife going deep. It's the only thing they want me to see. And I think they'll stop once I deal with you.
Player: You're not dealing with anyone. You're leaving - now.
Shadowheart: No. I'm where I need to be. The whispering's already quieter here. Once you're dead, it'll be gone entirely.
Player: Attack her.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The brewer drags itself to a bar counter, on which are two full mugs.
Thisobald Thorm: Drink, gulp it down, wet your whistle. Tell your story.
Player: What in all Nine Hells are you?
Thisobald Thorm: Son of Thorm. Sot of Sword Coast. Go on. Cheers, bottoms up, down the hatch.
Lae'zel: Hells. The curse has twisted this man beyond measure...
Player: Pick up the tankard.
Narrator: *Leaning in, you can see how the creature's skin barely holds it together. The bulge of its belly is on the cusp of bursting wide open.*

Thisobald Thorm: Go on. Drink, make it drank, be drunk. You and I both, to our good health.

Thisobald Thorm: Now tell me a story, a fable, a saga. Delight me.
Player: I massacred an entire Grove of Tieflings who thought me their protector.

Player: Mime a sip of your drink.

Player: CHUG! CHUG! CHUG!
Narrator: *Each swig is as painful as the last, but you remain in otherwise sound mind and body.*
Thisobald Thorm: I - I know you. I knew, I know, I am knowing.
NodeContext: Increasingly drunk, starting to rave
Thisobald Thorm: You want father's personal mysterious - (secret) - secret. No, not, never! Father said, ordered, commanded. Don't say it, don't say it! The cage. Her cage. Talk and... perish, die, buried. Buried in Thorm tomb. Father told me.
NodeContext: Fully raving drunk.
Thisobald Thorm: I can't perish - no, nay, neither. Too strong, too...
NodeContext: Beyond drunk, about to die but denying it. Trails off at the end with a painful groan.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours. Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Secrecy.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure. We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.

Withers: We meet again, as predicted. I shall be here in thy camp, for whenever thou hast need of my services.
Player: Not to be rude, but what are you?
Withers: There are many answers to that question. None are important.
Player: Skeletons aren't supposed to be able to talk.
Withers: Correct.
Player: Are you going to explain further?
Withers: No. No.
Player: You were sorting something before. What were you doing? Impressive. Are there other ways you can help us?
Withers: Should thou or any of thy compatriots perish, I will cleave soul to body once more.
Player: That's incredibly powerful magic. Why is it so easy for you?
Withers: Because it is my calling. There is little else to explain.
Player: I could use those resurrection services right now.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_1_c85cdca4-6579-776d-206d-6967e4999281].
Withers: This is the price of balance. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Actually, there's something else I need from you.
Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: Please bring back Lae'zel. I can't live with what I did.
Withers: Thou didst not kill thine own friend. Thou offered thy friend as sacrifice. Their soul is in a place even I cannot peer into. A place no soul should venture. Death alone was not suffering enough for thine Urge. Thou shouldst fear thyself. Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: I would like to collect one of my fallen companions.
Withers: Which of them dost thou require?
Player: I'd like you to return Jaheira. Here's the gold.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: My ardents spoke of one of our kin that escaped a crashing ghaik slave-vessel.
Lae'zel: Ch'r'ai. Vlaakith's justice in flesh.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much, child. I am pleased to finally meet you. You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you. It must not have been easy to escape. I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares. You also killed Sarth Baretha. She was formidable. To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us. The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.
Player: I can't. It protects me.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Indeed? And what does it protect you from?
Player: All kinds of bad things. It's my lucky charm.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You really have no idea what it is, do you? But you were not wrong to observe that you need protection. Once the Grand Design comes into effect and the Illithid Empire is restored, all life will be over as you know it. We took an interest in you when you became involved with this 'Absolute' cult. A pestilence of infected slaves - the first symptom of the Grand Design in action. But you are lucky - that weapon you carry is the solution. I have heard it from Queen Vlaakith herself. Hand it over.
Player: I thought the Grand Design was a ghaik philosophy, not an actual plan.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The Grand Design is what all ghaik seek. The restoration of the Illithid Empire, which spanned the entirety of the multiverse. For centuries, their elder brains sought to bring back their dominion. Every plot they hatched, we stopped. But now, they are close to succeeding. Never before could they pause ceremorphosis. Never before could they let the infection spread undetected. This is what we have all been training for. You saw the thralls gathered on the ghaik ship. It was a vision of the future. Luckily, our queen is here to guide us. She will lead us to victory. So. The weapon. Please.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't give it to him.
Player: I won't let you take it.
Lae'zel: Do not try me. Hand over the artefact, or die by my hand.
NodeContext: Threatening and confident. She means what she says.
Player: Remember the zaith'isk? These gith can't be trusted. Follow my lead - I'll choose the right path.

Narrator: *The guard insists that you meet with their leader - a Harper by the name of Jaheira.*

Jaheira: Hello.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Harpers draw their weapons.

Jaheira: An act of kindness, or a clever decoy. Luckily, I know how to find out which. This is why we're here, you see.
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. She’s about to make a demonstration.
Jaheira: It is a curious creature that hides all manner of secrets. But if there's one thing that we know -
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. She’s about to make a demonstration.
Jaheira: - it's that it knows its own kind.

Jaheira: A True Soul with a mind of their own... How is that possible? How is that possible?

Oliver: Boo! I scared you - I saw it. Nobody beats me at hide and seek.
Halsin: That's him - like an echo of Thaniel, remoulded by the curse. We need him, if we're to put a stop to all of this.
NodeContext: Urgent, determined. Whispered, so not to alert Oliver.
Oliver: Will you play with me?
Player: Don't startle people like that - easy way to wind up killed by mistake.
Oliver: Killed? Nobody dies around here, silly. Not like that. Play with me, and you'll see for yourself.
Player: In a moment maybe. Have you seen another little boy? His name is Thaniel.
Oliver: I don't know anyone called that. Don't ask me again. Now play with me. Killed? Nobody dies around here, silly. Not like that. Play with me, and you'll see for yourself.
Player: In a moment maybe. Have you seen another little boy? His name is Thaniel.
Oliver: I don't know anyone called that. Don't ask me again. Now play with me. Killed? Nobody dies around here, silly. Not like that. Play with me, and you'll see for yourself.
Player: You're not what you say you are. I can sense it.
Oliver: I don't know what you mean. I'm just me. I have a mummy, a daddy, a pet doggy. I have a mummy, a daddy, and a doggy. They'll be back in a while. But you're here now. And I want to play.
Player: In a moment maybe. Have you seen another little boy? His name is Thaniel.
Oliver: I don't know anyone called that. Don't ask me again. Now play with me. Killed? Nobody dies around here, silly. Not like that. Play with me, and you'll see for yourself.

Player: What are your parents' names? Maybe I can find them.
Oliver: They don't need names. They just need to be mummy and daddy, and do what I want. Now play with me, or they'll be angry with you.
Narrator: *The boy doesn't like these questions - because he has no real answers. And perhaps no real family.*
Player: Face facts, kid. Your family's dead - and you might be too.
Oliver: You shouldn't be nasty. You should just do what I want. It's easier for you, that way. I'm not going anywhere. I like it here. Now play with me, or else.
Player: You want to play? Fine.
Oliver: All right. I'll hide, and you seek.
Halsin: Let's make this quick. We need to reunite him with Thaniel.
NodeContext: Urgent. Whispered.
Oliver: Find me, and you win.
Player: I've changed my mind. You're on your own.

Player: I see some familiar faces, but where's everyone else?
Alfira: You don't know? Stars above... We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: How did you survive?
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: It helps to remember what is at stake - I fight for nature, for balance. I fight for life itself.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I'll do everything in my power to save them - you have my most solemn vow.

Karlach: Could have sworn I told you to piss off. Maybe I imagined it.
 Anyhow. Piss off.
Player: I met the people looking for you. They say you're a killer - a fiend.
Karlach: And you believe them? Those bastards are trying to feed you a crock of shit. Don't sweat it - devils are tricky fuckers. They can't breathe without lying.
Player: Hold on - the people I spoke to were paladins, not devils.
Karlach: Sure they were - and I'm Tiamat's left tit. I guess they told you I bite the heads off babies, and paint myself in their blood. Truth's not quite so exciting. Come on over and I'll tell you the whole story.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~[reuse]The player approaches Karlach
Karlach: I'm a fugitive - escaped from the Hells, and those bastards are trying to take me back.
Player: You were in hell? So was I, not long ago.
Karlach: Really? You're serious?
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.* *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.* *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...
NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us
Player: Hold up - you fought in the Blood War?
Karlach: Yeah - with distinction. Now tell me what you just did to me before I make sure you can never do it again.
Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.
Karlach: Hold on a minute - you were on that ship? With the tentacles, and the worms? I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: Not many did.
Karlach: Poor bastards. I boarded in Avernus - that ship was my way out.
Player: You were expecting the ship?
Karlach: No - I just saw a chance and I took it. That ship could have been heading for Sigil or Limbo for all I cared - anything was better than staying. And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: Why were you in hell in the first place?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse. Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me. I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset. Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: How can I help?
Karlach: A gang of cultists cornered me in an abandoned tollhouse, not far from here. I took out a couple, but I need them all dead.
Player: If I do this, what do I get in return?
Karlach: You get a friend who spat in Baphomet's eye and lived to tell the tale.
Player: I'll do it.

Harper Branthos: Plan's simple: your brain-bug is the bait - they'll trust you. Lure them in, then we hit 'em hard and fast. Once they're down, you grab the lantern.
Kar'niss: We bring more to your church every day, my Queen. Your followers are legion.
NodeContext: Drider muttering to himself
Harper Lassandra: Go! We'll wait for your signal.
Kar'niss: Your faithful stand ready, Majesty. Soon we march. Soon the world will bow to you.
Player: Clear your throat to make yourself known.
Kar'niss: What's this?
Narrator: *The drider's eyes cut through the darkness, locking on you as your parasite squirms with excitement.* *Your minds connect and you hear a voice whispering to you. The Absolute? Or just the echoes of his fractured mind, reverberating in the darkness?*
Kar'niss: One of your True Souls, my Queen! How have they survived?
Player: I swore an oath - a powerful one. It will take more than darkness to end me.
Kar'niss: Ah, you swore an oath to my Queen! But if so... where is their lantern? You blessed them too, my Queen? Where is their lantern?
Player: Lantern? Is that what protects you out here?
Kar'niss: Our goddess protects us. We carry her sacred light to drive back the shadows. Yes, majesty, your light can shield another of your faithful. They will join us on the road.
Player: No - that lantern is mine, by order of the Absolute. Give it - now.
Kar'niss: Majesty? Is - is this true? Did I not serve you well? Very well. If it is your will, they can have it.
NodeContext: Drider throws the Moonlantern to the ground in anger
Player: Good. You may go now.
Brawler Vez: ...Whatcha mean 'go'?
Kansif: We can't go without you - the shadows would tear us to pieces.
Kar'niss: This is not her Majesty's will.
Player: I know dangerous terrains - you'll be fine if you stick to the path. Trust me. The Absolute has blessed you. You will be safe.
Kar'niss: If - if it is her majesty's will...
Kansif: You can't be serious. You know what's out there-
Kar'niss: IF IT IS HER MAJESTY'S WILL, THEN WE SHALL WALK! She will protect us. She - she must.

Alfira: First cultists nearly murder us, and now we have a traitor on the inside? Can't we trust anyone?
NodeContext: frustrated and tired of being scared
Player: Cultists? What happened?
Alfira: Stars, you hadn't heard?
 We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: How did you survive?
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: If he hadn't listened to me, maybe his brother and sister would still be here.
Alfira: Don't say that. When I think of what would have happened if Cal and Lia weren't there... How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - there is no greater thrill for me than the hunt.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Shadowheart: Doing the rounds, are you? You'd better get some rest. What were you two talking about? What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?

Kar'niss: And you? What are you? Apart from a torturer of lyres.

NodeContext: Recovering from the drider's attack

Wulbren Bongle: It's been a while, my friend. I saw the explosion from across the pond - should've known you'd be right in the thick of it. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you. But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Enough, Wulbren! Gortash enslaved us, forced us to build his Steel Watchers - but no more. Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: Toobin is right. It's over.
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check. You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren - enough! I won't watch as you poison your soul - and the brilliant future that remains to the Ironhand Gnomes. I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around. Kill Toobin, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention. I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: Walk away, Wulbren - I won't ask twice. LEAVE, LITTLE WULBREN. OR DIE.

Withers: Fate spins along as it should. Have you need of my services?
Player: You were sorting something before. What were you doing? Impressive. Are there other ways you can help us?
Withers: Should thou or any of thy compatriots perish, I will cleave soul to body once more.
Player: That's incredibly powerful magic. Why is it so easy for you?
Withers: Because it is my calling. There is little else to explain.
Player: You mentioned a cost - what is it?
Withers: A matter of coin. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: At least that's straightforward. I want to resurrect someone.
Withers: Very well. Speak their name and it shall be done. Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_1_c85cdca4-6579-776d-206d-6967e4999281].
Withers: This is the price of balance. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Changed my mind. They can stay dead for now.
Withers: Dost thou require anything else? Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_2_b1161c91-1bde-6a1c-297e-ee0bfc1a57c4]. Actually, there's something else I need from you.
Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: Please bring back Shadowheart. I can't live with what I did.
Withers: Thou didst not kill thine own friend. Thou offered thy friend as sacrifice. Their soul is in a place even I cannot peer into. A place no soul should venture. Death alone was not suffering enough for thine Urge. Thou shouldst fear thyself. Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: I didn't mean to kill Alfira. Please bring her back.
Withers: The bard's death is a weight for thine own conscience to bear. She will be left to the peace of eternity, where the Urge shall seek her no more. Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: I need to resurrect someone.

Questioner Sumera: You were adored, Minthara. Brought up from the darkness, and into the Absolute's light.
Questioner Jasin: She cherished you. But it wasn't enough - you were distracted by your own desires.
Questioner Sumera: Bloodlust. Murder. Chaos.
Questioner Jasin: And most damning of all, an unexpected weakness - a longing for acceptance, and affection. From a mortal.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have no right - hnngnn.
NodeContext: Through gritted teeth, holding back immense mental agony - cut off abruptly by a wave of psychic agony, which she reacts to with a pained grunt/sob
Questioner Sumera: We have every right.
Questioner Jasin: You are nothing.
Narrator: *Minthara's mind connects with yours. Not strong, as you remember it, but fractured... disintegrating.*
Questioner Sumera: Come to observe, True Soul? She is a lesson - none can rise so high that they cannot fall again.
Player: I hope her punishment won't be too severe - she tried her best.
Questioner Sumera: We are erasing her.
Player: Stand aside. I'm taking charge here.
Questioner Sumera: Yes - your authority is great. We can learn, watching you break what little remains of her mind.
Questioner Jasin: Her mind is yours. Break it.
Player: Reach out for Minthara's mind.
Narrator: *Immediately, your mind is swept into a greater vortex. A psionic storm with Minthara at its centre.*
GROUP_GLO_VoiceOfTheAbsolute: -CANNOT-
                   -hide-
-SUBMIT-
                   -embrace-

Narrator: *Her torturers are not dominating her - they are destroying her mental defences, and exposing her to something else. The Absolute?*
Player: Push past the presence, towards Minthara.
Narrator: *Navigating the storm, you reach the nexus of her mind. It is a wound, bleeding raw emotion and shattered memories. But she senses your arrival.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You came. I prayed that you would, but there are no gods left to me. This thing, that speaks inside me - it has all but destroyed me. But... it fears you. Even so, I cannot resist it while my tormentors live.
Player: I have a plan - fake obedience, and the guards will leave without raising the alarm.
Nightwarden Minthara: I would prefer to make these bastards bleed, but I trust that you speak from caution rather than cowardice. I will put my faith in you, and pretend to be their slave.
Questioner Jasin: Is it done? I did not feel her mind break.
Player: She is cleansed, as ordered. Were my methods too subtle for you?
Questioner Sumera: N-no! My sister only meant to compliment your delicate work.
Questioner Jasin: Indeed. Seems I have a bit to learn, yet. We ought to return to our posts, sister. There'll be plenty more prisoners to practice on.

Sorn Orlith: A new face! Looking for another chapter of dirty lore for your biography?
Nym Orlith: You have but to ask, and we can grant you a moment of pleasure. Don't be shy.
Halsin: An intriguing pair. Takes me back to my youth...
Player: How did you end up here?
Sorn Orlith: I used to work as a courtesan back home, and my sister as an artisanal masseuse, but men are treated like dogs by the Underdark's matriarchs, so we fled.
Nym Orlith: We found surfacers crave the body of a Drow like a drug. Life is easy in our line of work.
Player: I was once in your position, in a way.
Sorn Orlith: What was it like?
Player: I try not to think about it any longer.
Sorn Orlith: My... my apologies for prying. Pleasure is what I know, and what I do best. Here, I work to create it anew for myself each eve.
Player: If you're truly pleased with the work here, I can't judge you.
Sorn Orlith: I'd have to restrain myself far more than any play-bindings do if I worked in another field. This is a place where I can be myself boundlessly. There are so many who come to me speaking of a fixation that no one else has ever been able to share with them... and never will again. A once-in-a-lifetime moment of passion. Every day. What could be better? Don't you want to try it? Trust me, you don't want to miss my signature Menzoberranzan Love Trick.
Narrator: *Menzoberranzan love magic - a formidable practice, usually only reserved for pleasing the most insatiable matriarchs in the city of spiders.*
Nym Orlith: And is that your partner with you? What a gorgeous couple... perhaps we could come to an agreement.
Player: Menzoberranzan Love Trick? But you are Seldarine drow, why are you fooling your customers?
Sorn Orlith: Darling, we are not fooling anyone. Unless you pay for me to make a fool of you. You'll just have to see what is in store.
Player: You two look uncannily alike.
Sorn Orlith: We are twins.
Player: Aren't you at risk of inbreeding, if you keep working together?
Sorn Orlith: Since I came to the surface, I purchased an enchantment to bless me with infertility, if that soothes your mind. We are twins.
Player: Aren't you at risk of inbreeding, if you keep working together?
Sorn Orlith: Since I came to the surface, I purchased an enchantment to bless me with infertility, if that soothes your mind. We are twins.
Player: Delicious.
Nym Orlith: Our bodies will haunt your dreams.
Player: I would like to hire both of you. And I hope my partner will join us as well.
Nym Orlith: We want both of you, silly! At the same time.
Astarion: Ahem. Sorry, pet, I'm not quite comfortable with doing this again yet.
Player: Don't worry, I wouldn't ask such a thing of you.

Shadowheart: Doing the rounds, are you? You'd better get some rest. What were you two talking about? What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and Gale. You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: Don't play the fool, please. You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and Gale. You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: If that was any of your business, we'd have called you over.
Shadowheart: Wrong. Your business is mine. We're entwined, thanks to this. If we're to survive, we need to trust each other. You seem reliable. I think you know how important it is that we find someone who can cure us. Best if we focus on that. And just to be clear, come daybreak, finding a healer is our first priority.
Player: Let's not abandon all caution. This is unfamiliar territory.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here. But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell said Ketheric wants you to find a relic. That's all I know. As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him might just be the best way to gain access to Moonrise Towers.* *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Fine, if it'll spare me your bleating. The relic lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work... Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...and he will come. My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: I heard what happened - that people were taken to Moonrise.
Alfira: I keep replaying it... over and over in my head. We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Wandering into the darkness was a stupid idea.
Alfira: And I regret it with every breath. I had to watch my friends, people who can barely hold a sword, try to fight a pack of murderous zealots. All I could do was run.
Player: Only fools fight an ambush. Better to live and strike another day - preferably to the neck.
Alfira: That means a lot, coming from you. You always seem to take everything in your stride. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - there is no greater thrill for me than the hunt.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Player: I don't think you understand - I'm gutting you here and now.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I don't know.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: Tell me what you've learned about the tadpoles' origins.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you. I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem... I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha is dead. She was swayed by Shadow Druids. I had no choice.
Halsin: Kagha... This is my fault - I was her teacher. I will mourn her when I can. But there are other matters to attend to before that. Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.
 Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut. They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

Zevlor: Now that's settled. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Those goblins - have there been many attacks like that?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: You made it back from Avernus. Surely you can survive anything?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Let me guess: Your old neighbours called you 'devilkin' and acted like they never knew you.
Zevlor: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew. We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'm sorry. I've got my own problems. Enough about the ritual. I have my own problems.

Player: I've hunted you to the Hells and beyond. It ends here, Karlach.

Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Astarion: Now, now, children - let's not lose our heads. Figuratively or literally.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.

Player: It will mean my undoing, but... I believe you.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you. I heard enough druids died by your hand to make the deity Silvanus himself weep. I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares. Kith'rak Voss' made a mistake when he let you go. To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us. The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world. You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: So all of this was for nothing.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies. I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill. I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha was swayed by Shadow Druids. She nearly sealed the grove.
Halsin: Kagha... I should have suspected she'd take things too far. I'll deal with her when I can. But there are other matters to attend to before that. Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.
 Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut. They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.
Malus Thorm: Sick. Quite. But on the cusp of a cure:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure. We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: My magic has blinded me - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you. I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Balthazar: Fine, if it'll spare me your bleating. The relic lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.

Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: What wrong has this man done to deserve such torture?
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture. Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain... We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: You do me an honour, but I am not worthy. Show me the way of Shar - I beg of you. I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Rugan: Aye. The whole reason we're in this mess. Trinkets for some rich tosser in Baldur's Gate. He gets his shiny baubles, we get a handful of Tarenths.
Narrator: *Tarenths are the currency of the Zhentarim - a network of merchants and mercenaries with few scruples.* *Tarenths are the currency of a merchant network called the Zhentarim. Led by the mysterious Pereghost of Darkhold, their dealings are far from scrupulous.*
Player: Whatever your cargo is, I'll take it as payment.
Rugan: Listen - I'm indebted to you. And that's why I'm giving you a chance to walk away before you get yourself killed. You made short work of the gnolls... reckon you'd make shorter work of me and the boy. But we're not merchants; we're Zhentarim agents. Steal from us, and you'll have a price on your head.
Player: Zhentarim agents guarding a single chest. Curious.
Rugan: If there are valuable goods on the move, The Black Company's always involved. We're the grease that keeps the wheels of commerce turning. And we don't take kindly to people who meddle in our business. This is the point when a clever operator like you accepts my gratitude and walks away.
Player: You'll find I'm very persuasive. We can make much more coin than you would with your employers.
Rugan: I like the way you think. Didn't expect to turn this horrorshow to my advantage... but why not? The chest's all yours. Damn thing's sealed tighter than a Duke's pursestrings, so there's no point in trying to open it. I know a fence in Baldur's Gate who'll take it off your hands. Nobody will be the wiser. Don't try to cut me out of the deal though. The Black Network has eyes and blades everywhere. Crafty swine like you could make a name for yourself in the Zhentarim. Make sure to drop by our hideout. Pass phrase at the door is 'little serpent, long shadow'. I'll tell my associates to expect you.
Player: I already met your friends - we didn't get along too well.
Rugan: And yet here you are. There's not many cause trouble in a Zhent hideout and walk away. I'd rather walk away too. So let's say our goodbyes, and speak no more of it.
Player: You can leave - but your cargo stays.

Narrator: *As you get closer to the printworks, something odd happens. You hear it speak.*
Printing Press: Oi, gormless - not one step further! You are interrupting art.
Narrator: *You feel a dancing, mischievous magic sparking through air around the printer. A fey creature resides within.*
Player: A talking printer? Fey magic never ceases to amaze.
Printing Press: Are you addled in the head? I am no chattering contraption, I am a person. An artist. Name's Jelliwig. This is my paintbrush. I make sure everything that's in those big ugly article blocks becomes fine printed artistry. I'm a master pensman, I am. Now scram it. One mistake and the reputation of Baldur's Mouth Gazette crumbles to dust.
Player: I'm actually a great admirer of your work - may I see?
Printing Press: Ahah, someone who appreciates the art of words. And a celebrity to boot. You'll enjoy this. As it happens, the next edition has an article about you. Ooh, it's a mean one, too - real nasty. Ettvard must really have it out for you. Hard luck. Will require a delicate touch to spruce up. Think I'll need my number seven pen. Real sharp.
Player: You need to stop it from being printed.
Printing Press: I'm afraid I can't help you. I've got a good thing going here - letting you swap out a whole article might get Ettvard suspicious. I wouldn't take it too personal. Ettvard gets his lines from up top, then gets all worked up over it. Although, it not being personal doesn't change how shafted you'll be.
Player: Wouldn't changing the article be delightfully naughty?
Printing Press: A-ha! A meddler after my own heart - wonderful. Right. Let's get this article nice and loose... There. You'll need to find a replacement piece, of course. Make sure it's a good one.

Rugan: By the gods, you're a sweet sight. Are any of my crew still alive out there?
Player: No. It's a grim sight.

Rugan: We're bound for Baldur's Gate - got some cargo to deliver. But we've a stop to make along the way.
Player: Maybe I should come - see you don't get waylaid again.
Rugan: Thanks. But that won't be necessary. We'll find help at Waukeen's Rest. Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself. You should meet my associates. We've got our own drinking spot by the tavern - invitation only. Tell the fellow on the door 'little serpent, long shadow'. He'll take good care of you.
Olly: Rugan!
Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
