[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: Just kill them already - all this torture is pointless.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture. Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain... We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn? Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her. I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things. I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54]) Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself. When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: This experiment is exactly the kind of evil you're trying to disprove.
Havkelaag: The pursuit of knowledge is neither evil nor good. Only in the application of such knowledge should one take on any moral imperative. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse. I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Narrator: *The guard insists that you meet with their leader - a Harper by the name of Jaheira.*

Magic ripples and entangling vines start to sprout from the ground, trapping the party in place. Onlooking Harpers draw their swords. |

Jaheira: Hello.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Harpers draw their weapons.
Player: Back off. Now.
Jaheira: Nervous? I've an inkling you've reason to be. This is why we're here, you see.
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. She’s about to make a demonstration.
Jaheira: It is a curious creature that hides all manner of secrets. But if there's one thing that we know -
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. She’s about to make a demonstration.
Jaheira: - it's that it knows its own kind.

| (CINE) Her suspicions now confirmed, Jaheira stows away the jar. The onlooking Harpers eye us with a mixture of fear and hatred. |

Jaheira: You should never have come here, True Soul.
NodeContext: Grave. She’s passing a death sentence on us.
Player: Beseech your patron to help you.
Narrator: *Your request falls deep into the nameless reaches of your patron's home plane. It seems to be met with deafening silence.*
Mol: Stop!

| (CINE) Jaheira glances over as a small figure pushes through the Harpers. It's Mol. |
Mol: What are you doing? They're the ones that saved us!
Jaheira: They're the one who protected the Emerald Grove?
Mol: Yup. Didn't leave a goblin standing. Not so bad to hang around with either. Plucked one of my friends out of a harpy's talons. Knows when to be discreet, too. I'd pretty much trust them with my life.
Jaheira: A True Soul with a mind of their own... How is that possible? How is that possible?
Player: The Weave itself burns through my veins - perhaps the tadpole is afraid.
Jaheira: I've met no sorcerer that powerful - and I've met many. Now, speak plain - how do you have control? You sound so confident for someone who's so wrong.
Player: I routed your spy, didn't I? I know it's hard to trust anyone right now, but believe me: I am not an Absolute cultist.
Jaheira: Congratulations. You've earned yourself the benefit of the doubt. Hear me, Harpers! All clear, at ease!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: | (CINE) Those Harpers who still had their weapons drawn stow them way. The tension among them dissipates now that Jaheira has cleared us. |
Jaheira: I'll not pretend to understand what that artefact is, but I'm old and wise enough to recognise a sliver of hope when it crawls out of the dark. Tell me - why have you come here?

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here. But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Something called the Nightsong. Your notes were very interesting. Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: I had Z'rell's permission - that good enough for you?
Balthazar: Z'rell exceeds her authority. But fine, I'll overlook your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake. The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.

The Warden: You spark of the familiar. Do I know you, True Soul? Hm. Perhaps not - your face is rather bland. Whatever your business, a warning: none may speak to the prisoners - Disciple Balthazar was most clear.
Player: The rules don't apply to me.
The Warden: Is that so? If you are above the General's chief advisor, you must be most impressive.
Narrator: *Her smirk hides her intent - she's toying with you.*

The Warden: I'm sure you do. Alas, I am not quite convinced. Perhaps a small donation would help. I'm not sure why someone of your stature must converse with prisoners. Perhaps a small donation would convince me.

The Warden: Pockets running a little empty, are they? Disciple Balthazar's orders still stand - none may speak to the prisoners. You can go now. The Absolute thanks you for this generous donation, True Soul. You can go now.

Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.

Havkelaag: The pursuit of knowledge is neither evil nor good. Only in the application of such knowledge should one take on any moral imperative. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects. Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse. I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Karlach: What? Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: My sources say otherwise. Not a devil? Prove it.
Karlach: How should I do that exactly? Carve out my soul to serve with a nice side of turnips? If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Lae'zel: Control yourself, Wyll. I understand bloodthirst. But this is no time to quench it.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name. I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: It will mean my undoing, but... I believe you.

Shadowheart: What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?

Player: What do you mean?

Player: What do you mean?

Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and Gale. You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: What do you mean?
Shadowheart: You and that githyanki.
Player: No, you've lost me. No idea what you're talking about.
Shadowheart: Fine. Just don't expect my confidence if I don't have yours. And just to be clear, come daybreak, finding a healer is our first priority.
Player: Let's not abandon all caution. This is unfamiliar territory.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her. I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things. I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54]) Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion. When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: By your words, any virtue delaying patience would itself be unvirtuous.
Havkelaag: And therein lies your fault: you would have us argue in circles until the egg hatches naturally. Time we do not have. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects. Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Player: I'm glad you made it too, it's one hell of a curse.
Alfira: It wasn't the curse that did us in. We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I've seen a lot of nasty ambushes in my time - but that sounds among the worst. I'm sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Only the strong survive. You want to live? Focus on yourself.

He Who Was: Where lies your guilt?
NodeContext: Shadar-Kai speaks in a cold, calculated tone.
Madeline: The... Waning Moon...
NodeContext: Speak with dead style
Player: You look tough - good. It's more fun that way.
He Who Was: Stay your hand, and be on your way. I'll not raise mine against you.
Raven: *CAW.*
He Who Was: A fair point - perhaps this one could assist us. The murdered lie silent. The raven asks - will you be their voice?
Narrator: *The raven, the piercings, the general malaise: this is a shadar-kai. Tales and songs featuring servants of the Raven Queen tend to be tragedies.*
Player: Depends. Who murdered this woman?
He Who Was: She is not the victim. Nay, she is the perpetrator. This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her. Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back. They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: It sounds like she must be punished - thoroughly.
He Who Was: You see it as I do. I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand. Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: That's some powerful magic - how do you do it? Can you show me?
He Who Was: Such spells are ancient secrets, and closely guarded - but I could be convinced to share them with an ally. Your soul sparks with vengeance. With fury. This is your chance to torment a murderer. To make her suffer. Will you take it?
Player: I will - what must I do?

Narrator: *The guard insists that you meet with their leader - a Harper by the name of Jaheira.*
InternalNodeContext: Player was sneaking inside but was discovered by someone. Jaheira was called in crime dialog.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: | (CINE) Jaheira approaches. Haper Elifer is about to speak, but a stern glance from Jaheira shuts them up and makes them cast her eyes to the ground. Jaheira then directs her stern glance at us. Without a word she raises her right hand claw-like to chest height. Magic ripples and entangling vines start to sprout from the ground, trapping the party in place. Onlooking Harpers draw their swords. |
Player: Holy shit. It's really you. The Jaheira.
Jaheira: You have me at a disadvantage. Let me correct that. Hello.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Harpers draw their weapons.
Player: Back off. Now.
Jaheira: Nervous? I've an inkling you've reason to be. This is why we're here, you see.
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. She’s about to make a demonstration.
Jaheira: It is a curious creature that hides all manner of secrets. But if there's one thing that we know -
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. She’s about to make a demonstration.
Jaheira: - it's that it knows its own kind.

| (CINE) Her suspicions now confirmed, Jaheira stows away the jar. The onlooking Harpers eye us with a mixture of fear and hatred. |
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. The demonstration is done and she’s proved her point: we’re the enemy because we have a tadpole in our heads.
Jaheira: You should never have come here, True Soul.
NodeContext: Grave. She’s passing a death sentence on us.
Player: Beseech your patron to help you.
Narrator: *Your request falls deep into the nameless reaches of your patron's home plane. It seems to be met with deafening silence.*
Mol: Stop!

| (CINE) Jaheira glances over as a small figure pushes through the Harpers. It's Mol. |
Mol: What are you doing? They're the ones that saved us!
Jaheira: They're the one who protected the Emerald Grove?
Mol: Yup. Didn't leave a goblin standing. Not so bad to hang around with either. Plucked my friend right out of a harpy's talons. I'd pretty much trust them with my life.
Jaheira: A True Soul with a mind of their own... How is that possible? How is that possible?
Player: You'll just have to take my word for it.
Jaheira: You sound so confident for someone who's so wrong.
Player: I routed your spy, didn't I? I know it's hard to trust anyone right now, but believe me: I am not an Absolute cultist.
Jaheira: Congratulations. You've earned yourself the benefit of the doubt. Hear me, Harpers! All clear, at ease!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: | (CINE) Those Harpers who still had their weapons drawn stow them way. The tension among them dissipates now that Jaheira has cleared us. |
Jaheira: I'll not pretend to understand what that artefact is, but I'm old and wise enough to recognise a sliver of hope when it crawls out of the dark. Tell me - why have you come here?
Player: I'm here on holiday.

Karlach: Hold up. One more step, and I put a bolt through your eye.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: stands, holding the crossbow in one hand, her other hand pressed to a wound on the left of her stomach. She appraises the player.
Karlach: No sudden movements, or you're dead. You looking for me?
Player: No, but I see you're hurt - let me help.
Karlach: Hurt or not, I won't miss - lung, heart, arse or eye. Take your pick. Tell me what you're doing here. Now.
Player: I'm hunting a fiend - you fit the description.
Karlach: Somebody fed you a crock of shit, and you swallowed the lot.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Karlach lowers the crossbow, grimacing in pain
Karlach: Don't sweat it - devils are tricky fuckers. They can't breathe without lying.
Player: Hold on - the people I spoke to were paladins, not devils.
Karlach: Sure they were - and I'm Tiamat's left tit. I guess they told you I bite the heads off babies, and paint myself in their blood. Truth's not quite so exciting. Come on over and I'll tell you the whole story.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~[reuse]The player approaches Karlach
Karlach: I'm a fugitive - escaped from the Hells, and those bastards are trying to take me back.
Player: I visited Avernus recently - seemed delightful.
Karlach: Do you find this funny?
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.* *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.* *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...
NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us
Player: Hold up - you fought in the Blood War?
Karlach: Yeah - with distinction. Now tell me what you just did to me before I make sure you can never do it again.
Player: I didn't do it on purpose.
Karlach: That's what I thought - it was something inside you. I felt it. One of those godsdamned worms, from the ship. I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: You must have got clear of the crash site in a hurry.
Karlach: You're lucky I did. The place would have been crawling with cultists if I'd stuck around - and they'd have dragged us all back to Avernus. And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: What makes you so important to them?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse. Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me. I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset. Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: So you want me to kill the people hunting you?
Karlach: Yeah. Can you handle it?
Player: Yes.

Kith'rak Voss: Now, now, child - your pet means to speak. Tell me, pet: why shouldn't I run you through this instant? And as for you, tell me - why shouldn't I run you through this instant?
Player: Silently hold his stare and discreetly prepare to attack.
Kith'rak Voss: Hmm. You make good use of silence. Too many think hot air will save them... If I have no use for you alive, I'll have your death, slow and sweet. Understand? A vessel fell from the sky. We seek a precious weapon that was taken from it.

Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the giths' suspicion cannot be aroused. They cannot discover that the weapon they seek is right within their grasp.*
Kith'rak Voss: Help us find it and I will leave your blood beneath your skin, unspilled.
Shadowheart: Don't help them. Don't tell them a thing. We're dead if you do.
Player: I might know something. But it'll cost you.
Kith'rak Voss: You haggle with your own life, fool. Be silent and hold still...
Narrator: *He begins to move his hand in a quick flurry of gestures.*
NodeContext: Narration.
Player: Silently interpret the meaning of the gestures.
Narrator: *You realise he's casting Detect Thoughts.*
Player: Attack.

Sovereign Glut: ((*flesh-walker, tongue-talker. you look like the Rot, yet your presence soothes me*)) ((*far you've come. reach into memory - tell me of home*)) ((*reach into memory. tell me of home*))
Player: Fill your heart with memories of your most treasured places.
Narrator: *It reveals its own home in reply: a humid cove filled with decaying myconid corpses.*
Sovereign Glut: ((*duergar destroyed my people. I am a Sovereign with no Circle*)) ((*this Circle does not welcome me*)) ((*but I have heard the song. you mean to cleanse the duergar Rot. I mean to join you*))
Player: The duergar are dealt with.
Sovereign Glut: ((*but I have heard the song. you mean to cleanse the duergar Rot. I mean to join you*))
Player: The duergar are dealt with.

Player: The duergar are dealt with.

Player: The duergar are dealt with.
Sovereign Glut: ((*but I have heard the song. you mean to cleanse the duergar Rot. I mean to join you*))
Player: The duergar are already dead.
Sovereign Glut: ((*here, I break ground. from the dark will a mighty Circle rise. my song will fill the Grotto!*)) ((*death-doer - the Grotto may sustain but one Sovereign. in the Age of Glut...*)) ((*...there may be no Spaw. eliminate the other Sovereign*))
Player: Why not. Spaw's time is done.

Zevlor: Now that's settled. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: What is this place?
Zevlor: A druids' grove, dedicated to the Oak Father, Silvanus. You'll find its keepers just as thorny, I fear. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Those goblins - have there been many attacks like that?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things. We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Found sanctuary here, did you?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer. Enough about the ritual. I have my own problems.

Shadowheart: You're here. Just like it told me you'd be, gith.
Narrator: *Your mind rushes into hers - a storm of desperation, confusion and a will other than her own.*

Shadowheart: It took me so long to find you.
Player: Say nothing and watch the intruder closely.
Shadowheart: I can't sleep. The whispering won't let me. It keeps pushing me - to you.
NodeContext: On, " to you" SH's hand drifts toward a knife tucked into her belt at the small her back
Gale: Careful! She's about to lash out.
Shadowheart: I'm tired of being pushed.
NodeContext: Shadowheart lunges towards the player with a knife.
Player: Stare her down.
Shadowheart: Don't look at me like that. I can't... no. Say what you have to say.
Player: Attack her.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Our time has come, son. Together, we will usher in a new dawn. Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web. Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus. She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.
Narrator: *The Duke wants to keep Florrick's location a secret. Little does he know that you've already found and freed her.*
Player: Connect with Ravengard's parasite to seek information about Florrick.
Narrator: *Within Ravengard's memories, you find Counsellor Florrick. She is confined in a cell, right here in Wyrm's Rock.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready? Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web. Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus. She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.
Narrator: *The Duke wants to keep Florrick's location a secret. Little does he know that you've already found and freed her.*
Player: Leave the duke's mind unexplored.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready? Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: Don't you understand? You are infected with an illithid parasite.
Narrator: *For a brief moment, uncertainty clouds his mind, then dissipates. The Astral Prism vibrates in concord.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Don't speak such nonsense.
Narrator: *Behind Ravengard's eyes, something stirs. A spark of life, of self.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: ...help me...
Narrator: *Ravengard's eyes grow empty again. Once again, he speaks coolly and calmly.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: As I said. Baldur's Gate will ascend. Toril's first and only Grand City.
Wyll: Father, please. Come back to me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: Gortash is a tyrant. This 'new dawn' is a lie.

Rugan: Thank the gods that's over. Wish you'd been with us when the beasts attacked on the road.
 Might have been more survivors... I don't suppose you saw any of my crew alive out there? Are any of my crew still alive out there?
Player: All I saw was blood and guts.
Rugan: Damn it. I guess that's a no. Risen Road's more dangerous than ever. You're the first friendly face we've seen since Elturgard.
Player: Elturgard's a long way from here. Where are you heading?
Rugan: We're bound for Baldur's Gate - got some cargo to deliver. But we've a stop to make along the way.
Player: Maybe I should come - see you don't get waylaid again.
Rugan: Thanks. But that won't be necessary. We'll find help at Waukeen's Rest. Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself. You should meet my associates. We've got our own drinking spot by the tavern - invitation only. Tell the fellow on the door 'little serpent, long shadow'. He'll take good care of you.
Olly: Rugan!
Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: Read his thoughts.
Rugan: Shame we lost so many agents. But the chest is all that matters - Zarys'd have our hides if we lost it. It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: Read his thoughts.
Rugan: Shame we lost so many agents. But the chest is all that matters - Zarys'd have our hides if we lost it. It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: What's in the chest? Your cargo?
Rugan: Aye. The whole reason we're in this mess. Trinkets for some rich tosser in Baldur's Gate. He gets his shiny baubles, we get a handful of Tarenths.
Narrator: *Tarenths are the currency of a merchant network called the Zhentarim. Led by the mysterious Pereghost of Darkhold, their dealings are far from scrupulous.*
Player: The cargo. Give it to me. Or else. Whatever your cargo is, I'll take it as payment.
Rugan: Listen - I'm indebted to you. And that's why I'm giving you a chance to walk away before you get yourself killed. You made short work of the gnolls... reckon you'd make shorter work of me and the boy. But we're not merchants; we're Zhentarim agents. Steal from us, and you'll have a price on your head.
Player: If your bosses come after the chest, I'll kill them as well.
Rugan: Tougher bastards than you have tried. Let's just go our separate ways, and be thankful we're all in one piece. Let's go our separate ways, and be thankful we're all in one piece.
Player: You had your chance. Either way, that cargo's mine.

Harper Branthos: Plan's simple: your brain-bug is the bait - they'll trust you. Lure them in, then we hit 'em hard and fast. Once they're down, you grab the lantern.
Kar'niss: We bring more to your church every day, my Queen. Your followers are legion.

Harper Branthos: We'll wait for your signal. Go!
Kar'niss: Your faithful stand ready, Majesty. Soon we march. Soon the world will bow to you.

Kar'niss: What's this?

Kar'niss: Nere? A fickle, unworthy servant to our Queen. Yes, majesty, your light can shield another of your faithful. They will join us on the road.

Kar'niss: Majesty? Is - is this true? Did I not serve you well? Very well. If it is your will, they can have it.

Kar'niss: If - if it is her majesty's will...
Kansif: You can't be serious. You know what's out there-
Kar'niss: IF IT IS HER MAJESTY'S WILL, THEN WE SHALL WALK! She will protect us. She - she must.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: What lesson are you teaching these sisters?
Malus Thorm: The crux of our worship. Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure. We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: My magic has blinded me - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you. I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'm going to punish her - throughly.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: Peace - speak your truth. We will go from there.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: Don't blame others for what you did.
Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did. She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.

Withers: Ah, another. Thy name has been recorded. I shall be here in thy camp, for whenever thou hast need of my services.
Player: Not to be rude, but what are you?
Withers: There are many answers to that question. None are important.
Player: Skeletons aren't supposed to be able to talk.
Withers: Correct.
Player: Are you going to explain further?
Withers: No. No.
Player: You were sorting something before. What were you doing? Impressive. Are there other ways you can help us?
Withers: Should thou or any of thy compatriots perish, I will cleave soul to body once more.
Player: That's incredibly powerful magic. Why is it so easy for you?
Withers: Because it is my calling. There is little else to explain.
Player: I could use those resurrection services right now.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_1_c85cdca4-6579-776d-206d-6967e4999281].
Withers: This is the price of balance. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Actually, there's something else I need from you.
Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: Please bring back Lae'zel. I can't live with what I did.
Withers: Thou didst not kill thine own friend. Thou offered thy friend as sacrifice. Their soul is in a place even I cannot peer into. A place no soul should venture. Death alone was not suffering enough for thine Urge. Thou shouldst fear thyself. Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: I need to resurrect someone.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_1_c85cdca4-6579-776d-206d-6967e4999281].
Withers: This is the price of balance. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Changed my mind. They can stay dead for now.
Withers: Dost thou require anything else? Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_3_56966d5e-534d-4930-264e-050a2345db3d]. Here's the gold.

Shadowheart: What were you two talking about?

Shadowheart: You and that githyanki. What were you two talking about?
Player: We were just discussing the next steps.
Shadowheart: I see. I'd be careful with Wyll.
Player: You don't trust Wyll?
Shadowheart: Heroic types can be brittle, I find. Better to trust someone with greater flexibility. Let's hope we rapidly find a healer. If we're to survive, we need to trust each other. And just to be clear, come daybreak, finding a healer is our first priority.
Player: Let's not abandon all caution. This is unfamiliar territory.

Zevlor: Ngh. Mragreshem.
NodeContext: mrag-RESH-em. Means 'shithead' in infernal. Zevlor has just woken up after being punched in the face by Aradin. He's groggy and pissed off.
Zevlor: A cheap shot. I should've expected that.
NodeContext: Disgust in his voice. His idiot enemy clocked him.
Player: Are you all right?
Zevlor: I'll survive a sore jaw. Particularly if it's rid the grove of Aradin. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: Is there a place for tieflings anywhere?
Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded. But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Karlach: Gods, these are those tiefs? Their whole city was dragged into Avernus for a while. Zariel was delighted. When they made it back out, I'd hoped they got their happy ending.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'm sorry. I've got my own problems. Enough about the ritual. I have my own problems.

: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Hope can help. The Hammer is here, in this House - it's...

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.
Player: Formulate your questions using as few words as possible.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: Where is Raphael?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: BEHIND YOU Skipping across the planes, spinning plates, making deals with dukes and devils. He's a busy man. A business-man. But not a man at all, of course. He'll be home soon, though, and you better find the Hammer before he arrives. Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: Why has Raphael been following me?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: HE LOVES YOU HE LOVES YOU NOT HE LOVES YOU HE LOVES YOU NOT You're the key to his future kingdom. You're his crowning glory. He has what you need but you are what he needs. Not a cure, no, not that. But a Hammer to break your chains. Or his chains.

Player: Where will I find my contract?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: THE SAME PLACE YOU'LL FIND YOUR SORRY LITTLE SOUL WHEN RAPHAEL RIPS IT OUT The paper cage for your soul. Such a tiny thing, but it's one of his favourites. In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you. But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.
Player: No. I'm not telling you anything.

Lae'zel: Honoured kith'rak. May Vlaakith show us truth.
Kith'rak Therezzyn: You are not familiar to me, ra'stil. Do you bring news of the weapon?
Player: I seek audience with your Inquisitor. There's a traitor among you.
Lae'zel: They speak the truth, kith'rak.
Kith'rak Therezzyn: Hshar'lak among us? Whom would you accuse?
Player: Forgive me - I misspoke. There is no traitor.
Kith'rak Therezzyn: Then learn to tame your tongue. I will ask one last time: have you brought the weapon?
GROUP_Daisy: Don't tell her anything.
Player: I seek audience with your Inquisitor. There's a traitor among you.
Lae'zel: They speak the truth, kith'rak.
Kith'rak Therezzyn: Hshar'lak among us? Whom would you accuse?

GROUP_Daisy: Don't tell her anything.
Player: There's a mind flayer invasion in progress. Why is that not your priority?
Kith'rak Therezzyn: You are well informed. My crèche discovered the same. We know infected flock to Moonrise Towers. I reported the gathering masses back to Tu'narath. In response, they sent an Inquisitor. Instead of ordering an assault, we were told to join in this mad hunt for an ancient relic. Inquisitor W'wargaz has the Queen's ear, so we have no choice but to follow him in this folly.
Player: If the Inquisition seeks this weapon, it must be vital. Tell me of it.
Kith'rak Therezzyn: It is small. Angular. Metal. Adorned with tir'su script. Stolen by 'True Soul' heretics.
Narrator: *You realise she seeks the artefact you carry.*
Player: I don't know anything about it.
Kith'rak Therezzyn: And yet your face betrays you. You found it, didn't you? Ch'mar zal'a Vlaakith! Give it to me.
Player: No.

Karlach: Man, I slept like shit. Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: I've hunted you to the Hells and beyond. It ends here, Karlach.
Karlach: For fuck's sake, you must be half troll to have a skull that thick. If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Astarion: Now, now, children - let's not lose our heads. Figuratively or literally.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name. I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: It will mean my undoing, but... I believe you.

Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here. But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Something called the Nightsong. Your notes were very interesting. Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: You are a ship without a sail, necromancer. You need allies - you need me. It's simple - you need me. Don't pretend otherwise.
Balthazar: ...Fine. Your usefulness may outweigh your insolence - for now. There are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work... Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: Just kill them already - all this torture is pointless.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture. Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure. We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well. And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution. How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.

Nightwarden Minthara: The goblins tell me that you extracted a confession from our prisoner, True Soul. Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul, jaluk? Perhaps you are worthy to assist me. It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to part from you. It does not want to fall into the Absolute's clutches.* *Her mind focuses - the cultists cannot discover that the weapon they seek is within their grasp.* *The drow's mind closes around yours, her bloodlust like needles in your skull.*
Player: Leading her to the tieflings might doom them... but it would earn her trust.
Nightwarden Minthara: My patience wears thin, True Soul. The hunt must begin. Show me the grove. Be my eyes.
Narrator: *Images of the battle at the gate shimmer into view, along with the adventurers pleading to be let inside.* *Tiefling faces flicker into view as she attempts to learn the grove's location.*
Player: Get out of my mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: Destroying this place is the Absolute's will. Would you defy Her?
Player: Open your mind to her.
Narrator: *She sees the entrance to the grove as the adventurers retreat inside, joining the tieflings...* *...and then smiles serenely as blood and shadow spread like stains across your memory, erasing all that live there.*
Nightwarden Minthara: The cowards found refuge among the desperate. Perfect. If the inhabitants do not realise you are the knife at their throats, we can use that against them. Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I don't have the most trustworthy face.
Nightwarden Minthara: They're half-devil refugees... Nobody wants them. A drowning creature will cling to a blade if nothing else is offered. Be that blade. I will gather a raiding party and move into position. You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike. We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name. And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: It shall be so.

Kar'niss: We bring more to your church every day, my Queen. Your followers are legion.

Kar'niss: You blessed them too, my Queen? Where is their lantern?
Player: The Absolute guided me to you. She said I was to take yours.

Kar'niss: IF IT IS HER MAJESTY'S WILL, THEN WE SHALL WALK! She will protect us. She - she must.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her. I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things. I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54]) Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion. When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you're planning to torture a child for a year?
Havkelaag: The child will be a better individual after my treatment than it ever would have been had it been raised in its natural environment. Any suffering it endures will therefore be worth it, for the child, perhaps for the whole of civilised society. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse. I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Something called the Nightsong. Your notes were very interesting. Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: Because I am magical powerhouse. You need me, and you know it. It's simple - you need me. Don't pretend otherwise.
Balthazar: ...Fine. Your usefulness may outweigh your insolence - for now. There are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.

Karlach: I'm exhausted. Weird. Hey, soldier.
Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?
Karlach: Hey, soldier.
Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Player: I've hunted you to the Hells and beyond. It ends here, Karlach.
Karlach: For fuck's sake, you must be half troll to have a skull that thick. If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Lae'zel: Control yourself, Wyll. I understand bloodthirst. But this is no time to quench it.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Player: How can I make peace with the monster I was sent to kill?
Karlach: You know monsters, right? Better than anyone. Look into my eyes. Can't you see I'm not what you think?
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Player: Dammit. This is an unwelcome complication.

Narrator: *The gnomes speak in soft whispers, the words all but lost in the hot air.*
Player: Eavesdrop on the conversation.
Lunkbug: We'll never get through. We need that smokepowder.

Apprentice Laridda: Philomeen's gone. And if she's smart, she won't be coming back.
NodeContext: Whispered

NodeContext: Whispered
Apprentice Laridda: Forget the smokepowder - there could be more slavers out there. You'd draw them right to her!
NodeContext: Whispered
Apprentice Laridda: Forget the smokepowder - they'd kill Phil on the spot. I won't let you do it.
NodeContext: Whispered

Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.

Apprentice Laridda: Lunkbug, don't.
NodeContext: Pleading with Lunkbug not to say anything.

We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map. If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Shadowheart: Sounds like an unnecessary risk to me. Though that hasn't stopped us before.
Player: Excellent. I can add Philomeen's head to my collection.

Player: I see some familiar faces, but where's everyone else?
Alfira: You don't know? Stars above... We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
 Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I'm so sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: Rolan? The apprentice wizard?
Alfira: Yes. He shielded me and the kids while his brother and sister rushed the cultists. Cal and Lia were dragged away, along with the others. Rolan isn't... taking it so well. None of us, to be honest. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Just take it one step at a time.
Alfira: You make it sound so easy - but I'll try. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Rugan: By the gods, you're a sweet sight. Are any of my crew still alive out there?
Player: All I saw was blood and guts.
Rugan: Damn it. I guess that's a no. Risen Road's more dangerous than ever. You're the first friendly face we've seen since Elturgard.
Player: Elturgard's a long way from here. Where are you heading?
Rugan: We're bound for Baldur's Gate - got some cargo to deliver. But we've a stop to make along the way.
Player: Maybe I should come - see you don't get waylaid again.
Rugan: Thanks. But that won't be necessary. We'll find help at Waukeen's Rest. Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself. You should meet my associates. We've got our own drinking spot by the tavern - invitation only. Tell the fellow on the door 'little serpent, long shadow'. He'll take good care of you.
Olly: Rugan!
Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: Read his thoughts.
Rugan: Shame we lost so many agents. But the chest is all that matters - Zarys'd have our hides if we lost it. It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.

This is the point when you walk away. This is the point when a clever operator like you accepts my gratitude and walks away.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.
Malus Thorm: Sick. Quite. But on the cusp of a cure:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure. We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: 'Only with sacrifice is mastery gained.' For the sisters to learn, you must submit.
Malus Thorm: Yes. Submit I must, into the Lady's dark-fingered embrace. I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Narrator: *The device is strange, made of taut flesh and pockmarked metal. It waits for something.*

Player: Go ahead, Lae'zel. You've earned it.
Lae'zel: Praise Vlaakith, let it be done.
Ghustil Stornugoss: Sit, child. Let the zaith'isk end your suffering.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The 'head' part of the machine descends and the jaws clamp around the Laezel's head, neck, shoulders.

She remains still, calm, accepting of the restraints.

She remains still, calm, accepting of the restraints.

Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I am a scholar, this is true - just not in the study of torture.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture. Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure. We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.

Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn? Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.

Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.

Sorn Orlith: Darling, we are not fooling anyone. Unless you pay for me to make a fool of you. You'll just have to see what is in store.
Player: You two look uncannily alike.
Sorn Orlith: We are twins.
Player: You don't actually lie with one another... do you?

Player: I'd like to hire your services, my lady.
Sorn Orlith: Ah, you're lucky, sister.
Player: I would like to spend time with you, lady Nym.

Nym Orlith: If your beloved one wants to join, we could work out something to our mutual satisfaction.
Sorn Orlith: Two of us, two of you. Four gorgeous people.
Player: What an idea!
Nym Orlith: We want both of you, silly! At the same time.
Astarion: Ahem. Sorry, pet, I'm not quite comfortable with doing this again yet.
Player: Don't worry, I wouldn't ask such a thing of you.

Narrator: *The guard insists that you meet with their leader - a Harper by the name of Jaheira.*

[description] CinematicNodeContext: | (CINE) Jaheira approaches. Haper Elifer is about to speak, but a stern glance from Jaheira shuts them up and makes them cast her eyes to the ground. Jaheira then directs her stern glance at us. Without a word she raises her right hand claw-like to chest height. Magic ripples and entangling vines start to sprout from the ground, trapping the party in place. Onlooking Harpers draw their swords. |
