Jaheira: Hello.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Harpers draw their weapons.
Player: Could you at least explain to me why you're doing this?
Jaheira: Absolutely. This is why we're here, you see.
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. She’s about to make a demonstration.
Jaheira: It is a curious creature that hides all manner of secrets. But if there's one thing that we know -
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. She’s about to make a demonstration.
Jaheira: - it's that it knows its own kind.

| (CINE) Her suspicions now confirmed, Jaheira stows away the jar. The onlooking Harpers eye us with a mixture of fear and hatred. |
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. The demonstration is done and she’s proved her point: we’re the enemy because we have a tadpole in our heads.
Jaheira: You should never have come here, True Soul.
NodeContext: Grave. She’s passing a death sentence on us.
Player: Accept your fate.
Mol: Stop!

| (CINE) Jaheira glances over as a small figure pushes through the Harpers. It's Mol. |
Mol: What are you doing? They're the ones that saved us!
Jaheira: They're the one who protected the Emerald Grove?
Mol: Yup. Didn't leave a goblin standing. Not so bad to hang around with either. Saved one of my friends from a druid with a snake. Knows when to be discreet, too. I'd pretty much trust them with my life.
Jaheira: A True Soul with a mind of their own... How is that possible? How is that possible?
Player: I work in mysterious ways.
Jaheira: Enlighten me. Now. You sound so confident for someone who's so wrong.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: | (CINE) The player takes Orpheus from their pocket and presents it to Jaheira who looks on intrigued. Player: I'm glad you made it too, it's one hell of a curse.
Alfira: It wasn't the curse that did us in. We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Asharak again?
Alfira: Which...? Back in the grove, he ran drills with the kids. Wooden swords and the like. That seems like a lifetime ago now. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: I take what I'm due and I don't look back.
Alfira: That sounds quite freeing - but I don't have that option, I'm afraid. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence? It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on. In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope. He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored. He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.

Player: Stop stalling.
Raphael: As you wish. Brace yourself, Astarion - we're about to unveil your destiny. And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny. As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr. In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed. The Rite of Profane Ascension. It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical. If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant. All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living. The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike you, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun. But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend. Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air. The only missing ingredient is Astarion. You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life. And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: Cazador is a piece of shit. We're going to stop him.
Astarion: Do you think it's so simple? What do you think I should do?
Player: We can't let Cazador complete that ritual. He could unleash terrible horrors.
Astarion: The end of my life among them. Just when I was starting to enjoy it. He'll never leave me alone. I didn't think he would when I was just one more wretched toy for him to play with. But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faerûn. I need to take the fight to him. And I need you to help me.
Player: Of course I'll help. We'll hunt him down and kill him.

Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul. I'd like to offer my services, if you're willing?
Player: What does a 'trader in blood' do exactly?
Araj Oblodra: I trade in blood and the potions that can be wrung from it. I'm more than happy to make you one, if you'd honour me with your blood. With one drop, I can brew a rather potent potion for you. The rest, I keep for myself.
Player: No, I'm not interested.
Araj Oblodra: I'm here should you change your mind. There we are. All of your very best traits in a bottle. Use it well! Although perhaps there's one more thing we could discuss: your vampiric friend.
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did. I assume he belongs to you?
Player: We travel together - that's all.
Araj Oblodra: Ah, it's like that. Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it. I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it. It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?
Player: Just bite her - the potion sounds useful.
Astarion: I'm sorry, but could you excuse us a moment? Are you actually asking me to do this? Trading me for some potion? Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.
Player: Her house, Oblodra, was infamous for experimenting with mind flayers. Could her blood be tainted somehow?
Astarion: That would explain the stench, yes. I already have enough illithid filth in my head - I don't want it in my stomach as well.
Araj Oblodra: I don't have all day, True Soul.
Player: Don't do anything you don't want to.
Astarion: All right. Thank you. It's still a no, I'm afraid.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence? It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on. In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope. He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored. He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.

Player: Are you sure you want to know, Astarion? Maybe it's best left in the past.
Astarion: Even if I wanted to walk away from all of this, I can't. Cazador won't let me.
Raphael: And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny. As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr. In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed. The Rite of Profane Ascension. It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical. If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant. All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living. The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike you, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun. But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend. Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air. The only missing ingredient is Astarion. You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life. And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.

It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on. In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope. He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored. He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.

Player: Please, give me more boring details about your plans.
Raphael: Come now, we're about to unveil your destiny - you should be quivering in anticipation.
 And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny. As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr. In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed. The Rite of Profane Ascension. It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical. If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant. All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living. The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun. But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend. Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air. The only missing ingredient is Astarion. You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life. And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...

Astarion: I was... contemplating. It's a lot to take in. What do you think I should do?
Player: I think you should run. If Cazador can't find you, he can't complete his ritual.

Astarion: How long do you think I can run? He has eternity to find me. He'll never leave me alone. I didn't think he would when I was just one more wretched toy for him to play with. But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faerûn. I need to take the fight to him. And I need you to help me.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed. And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team. And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us. It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: An old flame?
Nightwarden Minthara: Jealous? You needn't be -  when Orin is in my hands, her agony will nourish me. She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies. Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable. If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it. She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute. Now I know that those memories are lies. There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear. I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.
Player: Tempting, but eradicating the brain may be wiser, to put an end to this madness.
Nightwarden Minthara: Madness would be to let the Absolute's potential go to waste. The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: It's going to be glorious - I can hardly wait.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered. Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: When punishment is needed, my hand will not shy from the blade.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Karlach: Pot, meet kettle.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: Don't blame others for what you did.
Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did. She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Prove you're sorry. Do it for Ben and Marc.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Did I say stop? Drive the knife in deeper.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player enters a gore-soaked alcove and approaches the displacer.There's various severed heads on display - people and monsters. A pile of eviscerated corpses forms a throne-chaise.
There's suddenly a loud click from above (implied to be the orthon racking/loading its crossbow). The player looks up.
The orthon looms on a gallery/crumpling floor overlooking the alcove. It aims a crossbow at the player. Flanking it are several merregons.
There's suddenly a loud click from above (implied to be the orthon racking/loading its crossbow). The player looks up.
The orthon looms on a gallery/crumpling floor overlooking the alcove. It aims a crossbow at the player. Flanking it are several merregons.
Yurgir: What's this? Fresh entertainment. But you're too fresh for this place, aren't you? You've got the stench of the Hells about you - the stench of home. And a whiff of the surface besides. A servant of Zariel, if I'm not mistaken. I'd know the stench of her infernal machinery anywhere. You trying to burrow back home, little rabbit?
Player: What do you know about infernal machinery?
Yurgir: Only what I can smell. And whatever engine burns within you is grinding to an inevitable explosion. Burning and fear - you reek with it. ...There's something else, almost hidden by your fear-stink... cherries, musk... and sulphur.
NodeContext: Sniffing the air at the start, detecting something - then erupting with fury at the end on 'sulphur'.
Yurgir: Raphael! I can smell him all over you. Where is he?!
NodeContext: Furious
Player: Wait - you know Raphael?
Yurgir: That perfumed trickster swindled me - trapped me.
Player: He wants you dead.
Yurgir: Where is he? Spit it out - Now.
Astarion: What are you doing? The devil told us to kill this thing, so let's stop chatting and kill it.
Player: Raphael could be anywhere. But let me go, and I'll free you from his grasp.
Yurgir: Bargaining, are you? A Kara-Tur warlord once tried the same - I made him watch as I ate his concubines and young, then fashioned a codpiece from his skull. You can't help. It's not just walls that keep me here. Not the traps, the dark or the creatures it hides. Something stronger holds me - a contract. Either I fulfil the contract, die trying... or forfeit my freedom. If I leave this place now, I'll become Raphael's slave.
Player: Raphael is a devil like all your kind - he deals in tricks. You probably missed a loophole in your contract.
Yurgir: Raphael is no foolish story-devil, his mind is different. Sneaky. Listen... Spill all the blood sworn to the night.
Silence all prayers; smother each rite.
NodeContext: singing, a cappella
Yurgir: Wander Shar's halls; hungry to slay;
Leave no Justiciar alive to obey.
NodeContext: singing, a cappella
Yurgir: Leave none to hear it, then be set free;
This song is your oath, swear, swear it to me.
NodeContext: singing, a cappella
Narrator: *Well, that explains where all the Dark Justiciars went.*
Yurgir: ...That's it.
NodeContext: A little knowing (double meaning in 'that's it' - the song has ended, but he also thinks he's stumbled upon a revelation in the lyrics.)
Karlach: Not surprised this guy single-handedly wiped out the Dark Justiciars here. Fucker is stacked.
Player: Quite bloodthirsty, as lyrics go. Have you considered some instrumental accompaniment?
Yurgir: I don't want to make it pretty - I want to silence it. Anyway, enough prattle. The lyrics are clear - all who hear the song must die.
NodeContext: Brutally matter-of-fact
Yurgir: Time to die.
Narrator: *You feel your patron's prickling flame at the back of your mind - and its diabolic words on your tongue. It wants to help.*
Player: Attack.

Crusher: ...thrashed 'is arm with my bare hands. Weaker than pixies, humans.
NodeContext: This goblin is in the  telling a story to the other goblins. We join the conversation in the middle.
Brawler Tiny: Oh ho, you got 'im good!
Crusher: And who're you? 'Nother pest? Everyone just barges in here, thinkin' they rule the world. Hah!
Narrator: *A strange symbol glows, marked on their flesh, and something within you stirs in response.*
Player: Lot of assumptions here. I don't think I'm better than anyone else.
Crusher: Everyone says that. And then they spit in our faces. But no more. Things're changin'. We got the Absolute on our side now.
NodeContext: He's proud of this and wants to rub into our faces that he's better than us because of it.
Crusher: Ya better learn yer place. Go on: kiss my foot.
NodeContext: bullying the player, he feels like they won't dare to refuse.
Crusher: Or I'll wipe that nasty look right off yer face.
Gale: I feel I should warn you that the average goblin foot is host to some two dozen toe-curling diseases.
Player: Ignore your lust to eat the foot. Get down to lick it.
Crusher: That's more like it.
NodeContext: condescending - he asked us to kiss his feet and we got on our knees.
Player: Kiss his foot and get it over with.
Narrator: *As your lips touch the filthy flesh, you catch a whiff of... lavender?*
Crusher: Ugh, didya see? They did it. Gross.
NodeContext: He's talking to the other goblins, surprised you actually kissed his feet and he wants you to feel really bad about it.
Player: Grab his foot and lick it.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence? It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on. In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope. He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored. He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Are you sure you want to know, Astarion? Maybe it's best left in the past.
Astarion: Even if I wanted to walk away from all of this, I can't. Cazador won't let me.
Raphael: And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny. As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr. In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed. The Rite of Profane Ascension. It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical. If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant. All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living. The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun. But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend. Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air. The only missing ingredient is Astarion. You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life. And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: You're... quiet. It's unsettling.
Astarion: It's a lot to take in. What do you think I should do?
Player: You'll never be free while Cazador lives.
Astarion: I hate how right you are. I knew he wouldn't leave me alone even when I was just another wretched toy for him to play with. But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faerûn. I need to take the fight to him. And I need you to help me.
Player: Of course I'll help. We'll hunt him down and kill him.

Player: You're right - I'll help you destroy him.

Nettie: Don't worry about him on the table. I'm not in the habit of killing drow. He attacked Master Halsin and I in the woods, leading a pack of goblins. Tadpole crawled out of his head soon after.
Player: The drow and I have the same kind of parasite?
Nettie: Seems so. Gave Master Halsin a right start.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Nettie turns to the desk, examining it until she finds what sh'es lookign for a long thron that's been removed from a vine.
Nettie: It's why he joined the adventurers on their expedition. To find out what was happening. A pity you got me instead of him. He understands these things - studied them. Still, we have options.

Nettie: You don't have to be here for this.
Lae'zel: I will remain. I've a vested interest in the outcome.
Nettie: All right, let's see what we can do.
Player: Thank you, I'll take anything that can help.
Nettie: Of course. Now, tell me what's been happening. Any symptoms? Strange events?
Player: I can merge my mind with anyone else that's infected.
Nettie: Victims can identify each other? Not that the others know they're victims, of course. How'd you pick up the parasite? Halsin was desperate to find where all this was happening.
Player: You're asking a lot of questions...
Nettie: Of course I am. Lives are on the line, and not just yours. So tell me, where'd you get that thing?
Player: I don't know, I just woke up with it.
Nettie: All right. I suppose that makes things easier. Give me your arm, please.
Player: Pull back.
Nettie: You came to me for help. Do you want it or not?
Player: Hold out your arm.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: JLatino: Nettie takes the player's arm and scratches them with the thorn.
Nettie: There. Be careful. Your legs'll probably give out first.
Player: Grab the branch from her.
Nettie: It's too late. It's already in your system. I'm truly, truly sorry. For what it's worth, the poison is painless. It'll be like going to sleep.
Player: Wait - you poisoned me?!
Nettie: Please, try to relax. This doesn't have to be hard. I'm truly, truly sorry. For what it's worth, the poison is painless. It'll be like going to sleep.
Player: Is there an antidote?
Nettie: You can't have it. I can't risk you turning - you'd kill us all.
Player: Attack her.

Astarion: Well hello. Welcome to my humble party. What's your poison? Red? White?
Player: Red.
Astarion: Ah, a good, full-bodied choice. So, what are we drinking to? Other than a pile of corpses.
NodeContext: Pouring you a drink. You both pick up your cups.
Player: That's not funny.
Astarion: Oh don't be so sour - it's a party. You did what you had to. Don't be ashamed that you did it well.
Player: I wish things had turned out differently.
Astarion: And I wish I was drinking out of Cazador's skull. Life is tough. Although that's not to say we can't have a little fun.
NodeContext: Toasts and drinks
Astarion: Mmm. Delicious. So. What happens next?
Player: Between us? Nothing.
Astarion: Nothing? How can you be so cruel? Come on. There's a spark here. I know you've felt it too, darling.
Player: Maybe. If you say 'please.'
Astarion: What?
Player: I'm kidding. I'll see you tonight.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'm here to make sure she sees justice.
He Who Was: There is no justice for traitors - only pain. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: Blood taints all our hands in ways we never predict.
Madeline: But - but this wasn't supposed to happen - I swear! I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: What did the Dark Justiciar actually do to your friends?
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Prove you're sorry. Do it for Ben and Marc.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Did I say stop? Drive the knife in deeper.

Astarion: Sounds like you've been learning all about your gruesome future. I have to say, I thought you'd look worse, but no. Not a tentacle to be seen.
Player: Not yet.
Astarion: 'Yet'. Of course, first sign of change and I'll have to stop that pretty little heart of yours. I am open to suggestions. Knives, poison, strangulation - whatever you'd prefer.
Player: Killing me would rather decrease your odds of survival. Dramatically, in fact.
Astarion: Don't be so pig-headed, I'm being practical. How much damage will you cause if you transform? How much blood can you bear to have on your hands?
Player: If I had to choose, I'd want the knife. Make it quick.

Astarion: Good morning. How do you feel?
Player: I feel awful. We won't be doing that again.
Astarion: A pity. Just be grateful I'm not a 'true' vampire. A bite from them and you might wake up as a vampire spawn, like my good self. All of a vampire's hunger, but few of their powers. Of course, I can't summon wolves or turn to mist like a 'true' vampire. Being a spawn has its drawbacks.
Player: Is that how you can stand in the sun? Because you're not a 'true' vampire?
Astarion: Oh no, I should be cinders in this light. I hadn't seen the sun for two hundred years before we crashed here. Someone - or something - wants me alive. They've changed the rules. Standing in the sun, wading through a river, wandering into homes without an invitation - they're all perfectly mundane activities now. As for my other quirks - well, we can figure those out in time.
Player: If I can help, just ask. We're in this together.
Astarion: Oh you're such a sweetheart. I'm just glad you're being sensible about these revelations. I was worried people might turn up with torches and pitchforks. Although there's still time.
NodeContext: Looks over his shoulder, realising someone's approaching
Gale: Well, we all have a monster inside us of one sort or another.
Karlach: Some of us more than others, but - yes.
Player: If you don't like it, you can leave.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player enters a gore-soaked alcove and approaches the displacer.There's various severed heads on display - people and monsters. A pile of eviscerated corpses forms a throne-chaise.
There's suddenly a loud click from above (implied to be the orthon racking/loading its crossbow). The player looks up.
The orthon looms on a gallery/crumpling floor overlooking the alcove. It aims a crossbow at the player. Flanking it are several merregons.
There's suddenly a loud click from above (implied to be the orthon racking/loading its crossbow). The player looks up.
The orthon looms on a gallery/crumpling floor overlooking the alcove. It aims a crossbow at the player. Flanking it are several merregons.
Yurgir: What's this? Fresh entertainment. But you're too fresh for this place, aren't you? You've got the stench of the Hells about you - the stench of home. And a whiff of the surface besides. A servant of Zariel, if I'm not mistaken. I'd know the stench of her infernal machinery anywhere. You trying to burrow back home, little rabbit?
Player: What do you know about infernal machinery?
Yurgir: Only what I can smell. And whatever engine burns within you is grinding to an inevitable explosion. Burning and fear - you reek with it. ...There's something else, almost hidden by your fear-stink... cherries, musk... and sulphur.
NodeContext: Sniffing the air at the start, detecting something - then erupting with fury at the end on 'sulphur'.
Yurgir: Raphael! I can smell him all over you. Where is he?!
NodeContext: Furious
Player: Wait - you know Raphael?
Yurgir: That perfumed trickster swindled me - trapped me.
Player: He wants you dead.
Yurgir: Where is he? Spit it out - Now.
Astarion: What are you doing? The devil told us to kill this thing, so let's stop chatting and kill it.
Player: Raphael could be anywhere. But let me go, and I'll free you from his grasp.
Yurgir: Bargaining, are you? A Kara-Tur warlord once tried the same - I made him watch as I ate his concubines and young, then fashioned a codpiece from his skull. You can't help. It's not just walls that keep me here. Not the traps, the dark or the creatures it hides. Something stronger holds me - a contract. Either I fulfil the contract, die trying... or forfeit my freedom. If I leave this place now, I'll become Raphael's slave.
Player: I happen to be an expert in such deals - and there is always a loophole.
Yurgir: Raphael is no foolish story-devil, his mind is different. Sneaky. Listen... Spill all the blood sworn to the night.
Silence all prayers; smother each rite.
NodeContext: singing, a cappella
Yurgir: Wander Shar's halls; hungry to slay;
Leave no Justiciar alive to obey.
NodeContext: singing, a cappella
Yurgir: Leave none to hear it, then be set free;
This song is your oath, swear, swear it to me.
NodeContext: singing, a cappella
Narrator: *Well, that explains where all the Dark Justiciars went.* *A fey giggle sounds in the back of your mind - seems as though your patron enjoys a tricksy contract.* *Especially one with a built-in loophole. The song's last couplet is a clause that's near impossible to fulfil.*
Yurgir: ...That's it.
NodeContext: A little knowing (double meaning in 'that's it' - the song has ended, but he also thinks he's stumbled upon a revelation in the lyrics.)
Karlach: Not surprised this guy single-handedly wiped out the Dark Justiciars here. Fucker is stacked.
Player: Bravo.
Yurgir: It's been some time since I had an audience. Any who hear it tend to die. Anyway, enough prattle. The lyrics are clear - all who hear the song must die.
NodeContext: Brutally matter-of-fact
Yurgir: Time to die.
Narrator: *You feel your patron's prickling flame at the back of your mind - and its diabolic words on your tongue. It wants to help.*
Player: Attack.

Crusher: ...thrashed 'is arm with my bare hands. Weaker than pixies, humans.
NodeContext: This goblin is in the  telling a story to the other goblins. We join the conversation in the middle.
Brawler Tiny: Oh ho, you got 'im good!
Crusher: And what're you doin' 'ere with that stink on yer face? Think you can do whatever you want? Think you rule the world, huh? And who're you? 'Nother pest? Everyone just barges in here, thinkin' they rule the world. Hah!
Narrator: *A strange symbol glows, marked on their flesh, and something within you stirs in response.*
Player: I don't just think so; it's a fact. You're nothing but dirt beneath my feet.
Crusher: Well, not us. Things're changin'. We got the Absolute on our side now. Ya better learn yer place. Go on: kiss my foot.
NodeContext: bullying the player, he feels like they won't dare to refuse.
Crusher: Or I'll wipe that nasty look right off yer face.
Shadowheart: Kiss the damn foot. Worse things have been shoved in your face lately.
Player: Ignore your lust to eat the foot. Get down to lick it.
Crusher: That's more like it.
NodeContext: condescending - he asked us to kiss his feet and we got on our knees.
Player: Give the foot a long lick.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence? It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on. In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope. He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored. He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Please, give me more boring details about your plans.
Raphael: Come now, we're about to unveil your destiny - you should be quivering in anticipation.
 And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny. As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr. In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed. The Rite of Profane Ascension. It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical. If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant. All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living. The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun. But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend. Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air. The only missing ingredient is Astarion. You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life. And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: 'Hmm'? That's all you have to say?
Astarion: I was... contemplating. It's a lot to take in. What do you think I should do?
Player: We can't let Cazador complete that ritual. He could unleash terrible horrors.
Astarion: The end of my life among them. Just when I was starting to enjoy it. He'll never leave me alone. I didn't think he would when I was just one more wretched toy for him to play with. But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faerûn. I need to take the fight to him. And I need you to help me.
Player: Not a chance.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: You're right - I'll help you destroy him.

Yurgir: What's this? Fresh entertainment. But you're too fresh for this place, aren't you? You've got the stench of the Hells about you - the stench of home. And a whiff of the surface besides. NodeContext: Furious
Player: Wait - you know Raphael?
Yurgir: That perfumed trickster swindled me - trapped me.

Player: Raphael could be anywhere. But let me go, and I'll free you from his grasp.
Yurgir: Bargaining, are you? A Kara-Tur warlord once tried the same - I made him watch as I ate his concubines and young, then fashioned a codpiece from his skull. Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence? It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on. In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope. He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored. He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Stop stalling.
Raphael: As you wish. Brace yourself, Astarion - we're about to unveil your destiny. And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny. As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr. In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed. The Rite of Profane Ascension. It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical. If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant. All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living. The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun. But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend. Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air. The only missing ingredient is Astarion. You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life. And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: You don't need to go back to Cazador - you're with me now.
Astarion: Do you think it's so simple? What do you think I should do?
Player: You'll never be free while Cazador lives.
Astarion: I hate how right you are. I knew he wouldn't leave me alone even when I was just another wretched toy for him to play with. But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faerûn. I need to take the fight to him. And I need you to help me.
Player: If he comes for you, I'll defend you. But we're not risking an attack on his lair.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: You're right - I'll help you destroy him.

Araj Oblodra: Araj Oblodra, trader in blood and the sanguineous arts. It is a pleasure to stand before a True Soul. And your pale companion.
NodeContext: With a bow. (Araj Oblodra = a-RADJ o-BLOD-ruh)
Araj Oblodra: I'd like to offer my services, if you're willing?
Player: Why are you interested in my pale friend?
Araj Oblodra: Please, you think someone in my line of work wouldn't recognise a vampire spawn when they see one? I trade in blood and the potions that can be wrung from it. I'm more than happy to make you one, if you'd honour me with your blood. With one drop, I can brew a rather potent potion for you. The rest, I keep for myself.
Player: No, I'm not interested.
Araj Oblodra: I'm here should you change your mind. There we are. All of your very best traits in a bottle. Use it well! Although perhaps there's one more thing we could discuss: your vampiric friend.
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did. I assume he belongs to you?
Player: Excuse me? He's his own person.
Araj Oblodra: I'm sure he really believes that. How utterly adorable. Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it. I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it. It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?
Player: He said no. There's nothing more to discuss.

Nettie: It's why he joined the adventurers on their expedition. To find out what was happening. A pity you got me instead of him. He understands these things - studied them. Still, we have options.
NodeContext: Previous line was murmured to yourself, the next line is very 'okay, let's get down to business.' This line should be a transition between the two.
Nettie: You don't have to be here for this.
Lae'zel: I will remain. I've a vested interest in the outcome.
Nettie: All right, let's see what we can do.
Player: Thank you, I'll take anything that can help.
Nettie: Of course. Now, tell me what's been happening. Any symptoms? Strange events?
Player: I can merge my mind with anyone else that's infected.
Nettie: Victims can identify each other? Not that the others know they're victims, of course. How'd you pick up the parasite? Halsin was desperate to find where all this was happening.
Player: I don't know, I just woke up with it.
Nettie: To hells with it.
NodeContext: Frustrated, about to attack you because she's run out of other options. She hunches down, ready to swing the thorn, clearly about to attack you.
Player: Dodge when she lunges for you.
Narrator: *You try to dodge her blow, but she catches you, scratching your hand.*
Nettie: There. It's done. I'm truly, truly sorry. For what it's worth, the poison is painless. It'll be like going to sleep.
Player: Grab the branch and try to identify the poison.
Narrator: *Not many thorns have such unique poison - it has to be Kelemvor's Kiss, a plant from the Dalelands. There is a cure but, try as you might, you can't recall it.*

Nettie: I won't. I can't.
Player: But I don't have symptoms - I'm not changing.
Nettie: Same as the drow... But Master Halsin said he'd turn eventually.
Player: Eventually? That gives me time to find a cure.
Nettie: Maybe, but it's one hell of a maybe. You could have days or seconds.
Player: As long as there's a chance, you're not saving me. You're committing murder.
Nettie: I'm sorry. There's nothing you can say to change my mind.
Player: Attack her.

In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope. He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored. He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Please, give me more boring details about your plans.
Raphael: Come now, we're about to unveil your destiny - you should be quivering in anticipation.
 And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny. As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr. In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed. The Rite of Profane Ascension. It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical. If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant. All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living. The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun. But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend. Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air. The only missing ingredient is Astarion. You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life. And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: You don't need to go back to Cazador - you're with me now.
Astarion: Do you think it's so simple? What do you think I should do?
Player: There's a way to become a living vampire... That must mean a lot to you.
Astarion: The idea definitely has appeal. I could get rid of the worm in my head and still walk in the sun. I'd finally be free of the hunger. And if I'm the key to this deal of Cazador's, perhaps I can turn this to my advantage... I need to take the fight to him. And I need you to help me.
Player: Not a chance.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: You're right - I'll help you destroy him.

Nettie: Don't worry about him on the table. I'm not in the habit of killing drow. He attacked Master Halsin and I in the woods, leading a pack of goblins. Tadpole crawled out of his head soon after.
Player: The drow and I have the same kind of parasite?
Nettie: Seems so. Gave Master Halsin a right start.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Nettie turns to the desk, examining it until she finds what sh'es lookign for a long thron that's been removed from a vine.
Nettie: It's why he joined the adventurers on their expedition. To find out what was happening. A pity you got me instead of him. He understands these things - studied them. Still, we have options.

Nettie: You don't have to be here for this.
Lae'zel: I will remain. I've a vested interest in the outcome.
Nettie: All right, let's see what we can do.
Player: Thank you, I'll take anything that can help.
Nettie: Of course. Now, tell me what's been happening. Any symptoms? Strange events?
Player: I can merge my mind with anyone else that's infected.
Nettie: Victims can identify each other? Not that the others know they're victims, of course. How'd you pick up the parasite? Halsin was desperate to find where all this was happening.
Player: I don't know, I just woke up with it.
Nettie: To hells with it.
NodeContext: Frustrated, about to attack you because she's run out of other options. She hunches down, ready to swing the thorn, clearly about to attack you.
Player: Don't be a fool. I'd kill you before you could blink.
Narrator: *She doesn't hesitate, moving quickly. Before you realise what's happening, you feel a burning scratch on your hand.*
Nettie: There. It's done. I'm truly, truly sorry. For what it's worth, the poison is painless. It'll be like going to sleep.
Player: Wait - you poisoned me?!
Nettie: Please, try to relax. This doesn't have to be hard. I'm truly, truly sorry. For what it's worth, the poison is painless. It'll be like going to sleep.
Player: Examine the branch - have you come across this plant before?
Narrator: *You try to find a clue among the thorns, but there's nothing. You have no idea what poison's tainted your veins.*
Player: Whatever this is, you had better have an antidote.
Nettie: You can't have it. I can't risk you turning - you'd kill us all.
Player: Attack her.

Astarion: Morning. I hope last night's little unpleasantness hasn't left a bad taste in your- Well. I hope there are no bad feelings.
Player: You're lucky I didn't kill you.
Astarion: And you're lucky I'm not a 'true' vampire. Last night could have gone very differently if I'd magically summoned a pack of wolves. Alas, I'm just a spawn. All of the hunger, few of the powers.
Player: Pity. I thought you'd be more powerful.
Astarion: Perhaps I am. For two hundred years, the sun would have turned me to cinders. Now I stand here like it's nothing. Someone - or something - wants me alive. They've changed the rules. Standing in the sun, wading through a river, wandering into homes without an invitation - they're all perfectly mundane activities now. As for my other quirks - well, we can figure those out in time.
Player: If I can help, just ask. We're in this together.
Astarion: Oh you're such a sweetheart. I'm just glad you're being sensible about these revelations. I was worried people might turn up with torches and pitchforks. Although there's still time.
NodeContext: Looks over his shoulder, realising someone's approaching
Lae'zel: A vampire among us? So be it. But should I wake with so much as a drop of blood on my neck, I will end him.
Gale: A word of warning, Astarion: I taste absolutely awful.
Karlach: Yeah. And I'm way too hot to touch.
Player: If you don't like it, you can leave.

Astarion: Well hello. Welcome to my humble party. What's your poison? Red? White?
Player: Beer, if you have it.
Astarion: You're a conquering hero and you want to drink foaming piss? Not that I'm judging, of course. So, what are we drinking to? Other than a pile of corpses.
NodeContext: Pouring you a drink. You both pick up your cups.
Player: To victory, of course.
Astarion: To victory!
NodeContext: Toasts and drinks
Astarion: Mmm. Delicious. So. What happens next?
Player: Well, I'd planned to bed you... Well, I'd planned to bed you...
Astarion: Does Shadowheart know that? I saw how she looked at you earlier. I don't know what her idea of a good time is, but it seems to involve you. I'd hate to intrude.
Player: Are you offering anything better? Because I could be persuaded...
Astarion: Let's wait until things quieten down a bit. Once the others are asleep, we'll find each other.
Player: I'll see you later, then.

Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul. I'd like to offer my services, if you're willing?
Player: What does a 'trader in blood' do exactly?
Araj Oblodra: I trade in blood and the potions that can be wrung from it. I'm more than happy to make you one, if you'd honour me with your blood. With one drop, I can brew a rather potent potion for you. The rest, I keep for myself.
Player: Sounds interesting. Let's do it.
Araj Oblodra: Just a little prick and it's all over. Close your eyes. A little pain for a lot of gold. And... There we are. All of your very best traits in a bottle. Use it well! Although perhaps there's one more thing we could discuss: your vampiric friend.
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did. I assume he belongs to you?
Player: Excuse me? He's his own person.
Araj Oblodra: I'm sure he really believes that. How utterly adorable. Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it. I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it. It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?
Player: I am surprised, Astarion. I thought you'd jump at a chance like this.
Astarion: I'm sorry, but could you excuse us a moment? Are you actually asking me to do this? Trading me for some potion? Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.
Player: Her house, Oblodra, was infamous for experimenting with mind flayers. Could her blood be tainted somehow?
Astarion: That would explain the stench, yes. I already have enough illithid filth in my head - I don't want it in my stomach as well.
Araj Oblodra: I don't have all day, True Soul.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed. And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team. And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us. It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: When I murder her, Bhaal will choose me in her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: I would prefer to put my faith in your strength than the favour of your god. After all, it is Orin and this grand deception that he chose - not you. He favours her, and she is one of the founders of this insane cult. Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable. If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it. She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute. Now I know that those memories are lies. There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear. I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.
Player: I'm with you.
Nightwarden Minthara: I expected you would be, but know this... What I propose is nigh on impossible, but if anyone can succeed, it is us. We have the Prism, and we have the courage to slay gods. And then we will need no gods. We will be their equal. We will be Absolute. We have a purpose and a bond. By my oath, I will fight with you while that purpose holds. We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose. There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain. Why come to Moonrise, where the cult's power is strongest? Why not walk away?

Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear. I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.

Araj Oblodra: Araj Oblodra, trader in blood and the sanguineous arts. It is a pleasure to stand before a True Soul. And your pale companion.

Player: No, I'm not interested.

Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.

Araj Oblodra: I don't have all day, True Soul.
Player: Don't do anything you don't want to.
Astarion: All right. Thank you. It's still a no, I'm afraid.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed. And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team. And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us. It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: So it's personal? Good - let's take her down.
Nightwarden Minthara: You make it sound so simple. She is the Chosen of Bhaal, Lord of Murder, and one of the cult's founders. Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe. It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power. Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored. Now I know that those memories are lies. There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear. I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: We'll be heroes - the saviours of Baldur's Gate.
Nightwarden Minthara: Let them think that. There is a short path from saviour to ruler - a short and bloody path. I know it well, and we will walk it together. But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it? In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: Stealing an entire cult is a new one, even for me.
Nightwarden Minthara: In the long history of these Realms, few people have attempted anything so bold. We may fail, but we must try. The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: It's going to be glorious - I can hardly wait.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed. And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team. And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us. It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: We must be free if we are to rule - and to be free, we must destroy this cult, and Ketheric's co-conspirators along with it. I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: An old flame?
Nightwarden Minthara: Jealous? You needn't be -  when Orin is in my hands, her agony will nourish me. She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies. Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe. It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power. Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored. Now I know that those memories are lies. There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear. I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Is vengeance the limit of your ambitions?
Nightwarden Minthara: There is no limit to my ambitions. I will enjoy killing Orin, but unlike her, I do not kill for pleasure alone. I kill to gain advantage. And we have the chance to seize the greatest advantage of all. Surely you see it? In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: A bold gamble. How can you be sure it's possible?
Nightwarden Minthara: I would have thought this entire conspiracy of gods and monsters to be impossible if I had not seen it for myself. We may fail, but we must try. The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: It's going to be glorious - I can hardly wait.

Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear. I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Is vengeance the limit of your ambitions?
Nightwarden Minthara: There is no limit to my ambitions. I will enjoy killing Orin, but unlike her, I do not kill for pleasure alone. I kill to gain advantage. And we have the chance to seize the greatest advantage of all. Surely you see it? In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: Stealing an entire cult is a new one, even for me.
Nightwarden Minthara: In the long history of these Realms, few people have attempted anything so bold. We may fail, but we must try. The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: It's going to be glorious - I can hardly wait.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed. And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team. And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us. It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.

Player: An old flame?
Nightwarden Minthara: Jealous? You needn't be -  when Orin is in my hands, her agony will nourish me. She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies. Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable. If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it. She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute. Now I know that those memories are lies. There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear. I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.

When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: Madness. We need to eradicate the cult and the elder brain.
Nightwarden Minthara: Madness would be to let the Absolute's potential go to waste. The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: It's going to be glorious - I can hardly wait.

Astarion: You know, I never pictured myself as a hero.
NodeContext: Looking around, holding a bottle of wine
Astarion: Never thought I'd be the one they toast for saving so many lives. And now that I'm here...
NodeContext: Reflecting. Holding a bottle of wine
Astarion: I hate it. This is awful.
NodeContext: Swigs from the wine, but it tastes foul. He pulls a face in reaction to the wine, but 'I hate it. This is awful' is referring to the party generally. He sets the bottle down on a table beside him.
Player: Really? Saving lives is awful?
Astarion: We killed some goblins to save some tieflings. The tally of lives didn't change much. But what do I get for all my hard work? A pat on the head and vinegar for wine.
Player: Take his bottle and try the wine.
Narrator: *It's a heavy, rich red - dry and sharp.*
Astarion: See what I mean? Awful. All I want is a little fun. Is that so much to ask?
Player: Knowing you, it probably is.
Astarion: Don't be so sour. I like a good time as much as anyone. You know, we could always make our own entertainment, darling. Get a little closer, so to speak.
Player: Maybe. If you say 'please.'
Astarion: What?
Player: I'm kidding. Once everyone's asleep, I'll find you and we can have some fun.
Astarion: Cheeky. I'll see you then.

Nightwarden Minthara: We must be free if we are to rule - and to be free, we must destroy this cult, and Ketheric's co-conspirators along with it. I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin. To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: So it's personal? Good - let's take her down.
Nightwarden Minthara: You make it sound so simple. She is the Chosen of Bhaal, Lord of Murder, and one of the cult's founders. Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe. It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power. Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored. Now I know that those memories are lies. There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear. I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.
Player: I'm with you.
Nightwarden Minthara: I expected you would be, but know this... What I propose is nigh on impossible, but if anyone can succeed, it is us. We have the Prism, and we have the courage to slay gods. And then we will need no gods. We will be their equal. We will be Absolute. We have a purpose and a bond. By my oath, I will fight with you while that purpose holds. We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose. There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain. Why come to Moonrise, where the cult's power is strongest? Why not walk away?

Astarion: I saw you getting a lecture from our magical friend. I have to say, I thought you'd look worse, but no. Not a tentacle to be seen.
Player: I could say the same to you.
Astarion: Indeed you could. We're all doing surprisingly well, given the circumstances. I'm not taking anything for granted, of course. First sign of change and I'll have to stop that pretty little heart of yours. I am open to suggestions. Knives, poison, strangulation - whatever you'd prefer.
Player: Don't make me choose! There are too many good options.
Astarion: Well, that's a little dramatic, don't you think? Come on, humour me. If you had to choose...
Player: If I had to choose, I'd want the knife. Make it quick.

Nettie: Yes? Is there anything I can do? Aside from the obvious.
Player: We can both see I have no symptoms - I'm not about to change!
Nettie: Same as the drow... But Master Halsin said he'd turn eventually.
Player: The grove is in terrible danger - cure me and I'll tell your leader how to save it.
Nettie: All right! Master Halsin thought the tadpole was dormant, so you have some time. Perhaps it's only fair I let you use it. But first - swear to me that if you feel any symptoms, you'll end things yourself. And? Will you swear you'd die before you turn?
Player: Attack.
